On average, the pair is tied with 50 percent each across several key swing states.\n\nIn his statement, Hughes shared a memo that said the poll of 3,102 registered voters sampled more liberals and fewer conservatives than a previous survey, and that Trump would be leading 51 percent to 49 if weighted correctly. \"The Fake News Media continue to help dangerously liberal Kamala hide her record of economic failure and soft on crime policies. Now, as this analysis shows they'll even put a finger on the scale of polling to inflate results for her,\" Hughes said.\n\nHe continued: \"This analysis is why the American people are seeing through it and will not allow this national gaslighting campaign to win. Despite this manipulated result, from CBS/YouGov it's worth noting that in July and August of 2020, their data showed Biden leading by 10 nationally, reflecting a net positive movement of almost +10 {"uri": "8260425011", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "16:17:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T16:17:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T16:15:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-poll-finances-kamala-harris-1934670", "title": "MAGA celebrates new poll that has Donald Trump losing", "body": "A number of MAGA figures have highlighted the findings of a poll that shows voters believe their finances will improve if Donald Trump wins in November, even as the survey shows the former president behind Vice President Kamala Harris overall.\n\nOn Sunday, a CBS News/YouGov poll of 3,102 registered voters found that Harris, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, is beating Trump nationally by 50 percent to 49 percent. Harris also had a 2-point lead -- 49 percent to 47 percent -- over Trump when other presidential candidates were introduced, such as independent hopeful Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who received 2 percent of the vote.\n\nWhen broken down further, the poll showed that 45 percent of voters believed Trump's policies would mean they would be financially better off, compared to 25 percent for Harris. Also, 44 percent of voters believed that Harris' policies would make them worse off financially, compared to 38 percent that believed the same of Trump's policies.\n\nAs the economy is widely considered the No. 1 issue of any election, supporters of Trump are suggesting that the polling results indicate he will be victorious in November.\n\nOn X, formerly Twitter, Fox News anchor Laura Ingraham shared the polling results and wrote: \"This is how Trump wins. If you vote for him, you'll have more money in your pocket. If Harris wins, you're going to be poorer. Period!\"\n\nChris LaCivita, an adviser for Trump's campaign, wrote in reply, \"It's really that simple.\"\n\nJohn Hawkins, a conservative columnist and the founder of Rightwingnews.com, wrote: \"Every time Americans go to the grocery store or pay their rent, they're paying a huge 'Kamala tax.' So many Americans are getting crushed by it.\"\n\nZack Cozart, a former Major League Baseball player, added, \"It's as cut and dry as it gets and a thousand percent correct #Trump2024.\"\n\nNewsweek has contacted Trump's and Harris' offices for comment via email.\n\nTrump has long cited the state of the economy during the Biden administration -- which has at times seen decades-high levels of inflation and record-breaking gas prices -- to attack the president.\n\nOn Monday, Trump used the sink in the stock market following a weak jobs data announcement in the U.S. to attack both Biden and Harris for their handling of the economy.\n\n\"STOCK MARKETS ARE CRASHING, JOBS NUMBERS ARE TERRIBLE, WE ARE HEADING TO WORLD WAR lll, AND WE HAVE TWO OF THE MOST INCOMPETENT 'LEADERS' IN HISTORY. THIS IS NOT GOOD,\" Trump wrote on Truth Social.\n\nThe CBS News/YouGov survey also showed Harris and Trump tied, with 50 percent each on average, across key swing states. The pair tied in Arizona, Michigan, and Pennsylvania, while Harris beat Trump outright in the battleground state of Nevada -- 50 percent to 48 percent -- and Trump led the Democrat in Georgia, North Carolina and Wisconsin.\n\nBrian Hughes, a senior Trump campaign adviser, accused the poll, which shows Harris with a narrow overall lead, of being \"fake.\"\n\nNewsweek has contacted CBS News and YouGov for comment via email.\n\nIn a statement, Hughes shared a memo that said the poll sampled more liberals and fewer conservatives than a previous YouGov survey, and that Trump would be leading 51 percent to 49 percent if weighted correctly.\n\n\"The Fake News Media continue to help dangerously liberal Kamala hide her record of economic failure and soft on crime policies. Now, as this analysis shows they'll even put a finger on the scale of polling to inflate results for her,\" Hughes said.\n\nHe continued: \"This analysis is why the American people are seeing through it and will not allow this national gaslighting campaign to win. Despite this manipulated result, from CBS/YouGov it's worth noting that in July and August of 2020, their data showed Biden leading by 10 nationally, reflecting a net positive movement of almost +10 to President Trump this election cycle.\"", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newsweek"}, "authors": [{"uri": "ewan_palmer@newsweek.com", "name": "Ewan Palmer", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamala_Harris", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kamala Harris"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_politician", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Independent politician"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Jr.", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Robert F. {"uri": "8260714248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "20:42:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T20:42:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T20:36:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2812712/", "title": "MAGA Celebrates New Poll That Shows Donald Trump Losing - ExBulletin", "body": "Several MAGA figures have highlighted the results of a poll showing that voters believe their finances will improve if Donald Trump wins in November, even though the survey shows the former president trailing Vice President Kamala Harris overall.\n\nOn Sunday, a CBS News/YouGov poll of 3,102 registered voters found Harris, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, leading Trump nationally by 50% to 49%. Harris also had a 2-point lead (49% to 47%) over Trump when other presidential candidates were introduced, such as independent candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who received 2% of the vote.\n\nWhen the results were analyzed, the poll showed that 45% of voters believed Trump's policies would improve their financial situation, compared to 25% for Harris. Additionally, 44% of voters believed Harris' policies would make their financial situation worse, compared to 38% who believed the same about Trump's policies.\n\nWith the economy widely seen as the number one issue in any election, Trump supporters suggest that poll numbers indicate he will win in November.\n\nOn X, formerly Twitter, Fox News anchor Laura Ingraham shared the poll results and wrote: \"This is how Trump wins. If you vote for him, you'll have more money in your pocket. If Harris wins, you'll be poorer. Period!\"\n\nRepublican presidential nominee Donald Trump at the Chicago Hilton Hotel on July 31. Trump supporters share new polling results that show voters believe they will be better off financially with the Republican as president. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump at the Chicago Hilton Hotel on July 31. Trump supporters share new polling results that show voters believe they will be better off financially with the Republican as president. More Scott Olson/Getty Images\n\nTrump campaign adviser Chris LaCivita responded: \"It's that simple.\"\n\nJohn Hawkins, conservative columnist and founder of Rightwingnews.com, wrote: \"Every time Americans go to the grocery store or pay their rent, they pay a massive 'Kamala tax.' Many Americans are paying the price.\"\n\nFormer Major League Baseball player Zack Cozart added: \"This is as clear and plain as it gets and a thousand percent correct #Trump2024.\"\n\nNewsweek has reached out to Trump and Harris' offices via email for comment.\n\nTrump has long cited the state of the economy under the Biden administration -- which has at times seen inflation at decades-high levels and record-high gasoline prices -- to attack the president.\n\nOn Monday, Trump took advantage of the stock market slump following disappointing US jobs data to attack Biden and Harris for their handling of the economy.\n\n\"THE STOCK MARKETS ARE COLLAPSING, EMPLOYMENT NUMBERS ARE TERRIBLE, WE ARE HEADING TOWARDS WORLD WAR III AND WE HAVE TWO OF THE MOST INCOMPETENT \"LEADERS\" IN HISTORY. THIS IS NOT GOOD,\" Trump wrote on Truth Social.\n\nThe CBS News/YouGov survey also showed Harris and Trump tied, averaging 50% each, in key swing states. The two men were tied in Arizona, Michigan and Pennsylvania, while Harris beat Trump in the swing state of Nevada (50% to 48%) and Trump led the Democrat in Georgia, North Carolina and Wisconsin.\n\nBrian Hughes, a senior adviser to the Trump campaign, accused the poll, which gave Harris a slight lead, of being \"fake.\"\n\nNewsweek reached out to CBS News and YouGov for comment via email.\n\nIn a statement, Hughes shared a note saying the poll sampled more liberals and fewer conservatives than a previous YouGov poll, and that Trump would lead 51 percent to 49 percent if it were properly weighted.\n\n\"The fake news media continues to help the dangerously liberal Kamala hide her record of economic failure and soft-on-crime policies. On average, the two men are tied at 50 percent each in several key states.\n\nIn his statement, Hughes shared a note indicating that the poll of 3,102 registered voters sampled more liberals and fewer conservatives than a previous poll, and that Trump would lead 51% to 49% if it were properly weighted.\n\n\"The fake news media continues to help the dangerously liberal Kamala hide her record of economic failure and soft-on-crime policies. Now, as this analysis shows, they are even going so far as to point to polling to inflate the results in her favor,\" Hughes said.\n\nHe continued: \"This analysis is why the American people are seeing through it and will not allow this national gaslighting campaign to win. Trump's campaign has called recent polls showing his judgment of Vice President Kamala Harris \"false.\" CHRISTIAN MONTERROSA/AFP/Getty Images\n\nThe CBS News/YouGov poll is the latest to show Harris ahead of Trump in the 2024 race, reversing the deficit President Joe Biden had before he dropped out of the race on July 21.\n\nSeveral poll aggregators show Harris outpacing Trump in national averages.\n\nAccording to the FiveThirtyEight national poll, Harris leads Trump by 1.6 percentage points, 45.3% to 43.7%.\n\nPollster Nate Silver, who founded the poll aggregator and now uses a similar methodology in his forecasts, also shows Harris ahead of Trump on average, 45.5% to 44.1%.\n\nThe social media account Polling USA, which aggregates national polls, gives Harris a 1.7% lead over Trump as of August 4.\n\nThe memo shared by Trump's team also said the latest CBS News/YouGov poll was \"entirely the result of a methodological decision to allow ideology to shift significantly, while maintaining the importance of age, partisanship and race so that the survey would not appear to have been manipulated.\"\n\nBill Mitchell, a conservative political pundit, expressed a similar sentiment on X, formerly Twitter.\n\n\"Why do people continue to act like these polls aren't completely fake? My friends, these polls are completely fake. Imagine if I published a poll with an R+8 sample,\" Mitchell wrote. \"Trump would be up 10 points. Do you think the media would notice? Of course.\"\n\nNewsweek reached out to CBS News and YouGov for comment via email.\n\nTrump has long cited polls that show him beating Biden in the 2024 race as evidence of his popularity and as a signal that he is the favorite to retake the White House.\n\nOn X, political commentator Ed Krassenstein, a frequent Trump critic, commented on the shift in opinion on poll numbers among the former president's supporters.\n\n\"The MAGA movement is falling apart. Kennedy Jr.; 2 percent would support other candidates such as Jill Stein of the Green Party; and 5 percent were undecided.\n\nThe poll also found that Trump and Harris are tied in a head-to-head race, with both receiving 48% of the vote, while 4% are undecided.\n\nKamala Harris at a Senate hearing in 2019 and Donald Trump at the Republican National Convention last month. The Keystone State is likely to play a pivotal role in the November election. According to aggregate polls by FiveThirtyEight, Harris leads the state by 1.2 points.\n\nSince launching her presidential campaign, Harris has made significant gains in the 2024 presidential race, compared to President Joe Biden's popularity before he withdrew. Trump has not led a national poll in more than a week, with Harris ahead by 1 to 5 points in the 13 most recent polls.\n\nThe Trump campaign had already warned his team of a \"Harris honeymoon\" period in the weeks following the launch of the vice president's campaign.\n\nAccording to a New York Times global poll, Trump and Harris are tied at 47 percent, with Harris trending upward in recent days. Including Kennedy, who is an independent, the Times finds Harris and Trump remain tied at 44 percent.\n\nOn Friday, Harris also pulled ahead in other key states where Trump previously led Biden.\n\nAccording to aggregate polls from FiveThirtyEight, Harris is narrowly ahead in Michigan and Wisconsin. Trump is ahead in Arizona, Nevada and Georgia. He led in all five states when Biden was still in the race.\n\nBeyond the improved poll numbers, Harris has also seen strong growth thanks to record fundraising. {"uri": "8262947184", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "06:11:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T06:11:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T06:10:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2813758/", "title": "Kamala Harris fares better against Donald Trump in New York than Biden, poll finds - ExBulletin", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris is faring better against former President Donald Trump in the White House race among likely New York voters than President Biden, a new poll released Tuesday shows.\n\nHarris leads Trump in the Empire State, 53 percent to 39 percent, a 14-percentage-point lead, according to the Siena College poll.\n\nIt is the first poll of a head-to-head matchup between Harris and the Republican presidential nominee in New York since the vice president replaced Biden at the top of the Democratic ticket after the unpopular 81-year-old incumbent announced he would not seek re-election.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris speaks at a campaign rally in Atlanta on July 30, 2024. AP\n\nA Siena poll released in late June found Biden leading Trump by just 8 points, 47% to 39%.\n\nBiden won the 2020 election in New York state by a whopping 61% to Trump's 38%.\n\nIn a six-way race, Harris leads Trump with 49 percent to 37 percent, with Robert Kennedy Jr. leading with 7 percent and the other three minor-party candidates with 4 percent.\n\n\"The landscape has changed since the last Siena College poll. The change in the Democratic ticket has had a noticeable, though not dramatic, effect on the primary race,\" said Siena College pollster Steven Greenberg.\n\nAccording to the poll, Harris has rallied the Democratic Party base.\n\nShe is outperforming Biden among women and black voters and is tied with Trump in key suburbs and upstate -- better news for Democrats running in competitive House races.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump hosts a roundtable with Black business owners before his rally at the Georgia State University Convocation Center on August 3, 2024, in Atlanta, Georgia. Getty Images\n\nHarris is supported by 86% of Democrats, compared to 75% for Biden in June.\n\nHarris received 81% of the vote from black voters, compared to 11% for Trump, compared to 59% for Biden and 29% for Trump in June.\n\nRegistered independent voters support Trump over Harris by a 47% to 40% margin. But Trump leads Biden among unaffiliated voters (45% to 28%), so Harris cuts Trump's lead by more than half among independent voters.\n\nHere's the latest news on Kamala Harris' 2024 presidential campaign:\n\nHarris leads women by 34 points, 64% to Trump's 30%, nearly doubling the gender gap.\n\nBiden leads Trump among women, 51% to 33%.\n\n\"The gender gap has widened since Harris replaced Biden,\" Greenberg said.\n\nTrump leads among men: 49% to Harris's 43%, almost the same advantage as the former Republican president, who had a 46% to 42% lead over Biden.\n\nHarris addresses the Sigma Gamma Rho sorority's Biennial Ball at the George R. Brown Convention Center on July 31, 2024. ZUMAPRESS.com\n\nThe former president also showed strength with two traditionally Democratic voters: Jews and Hispanics. He split the Jewish vote with Harris (50% to 49%) and Latinos (47% to 48%).\n\nInterestingly, it was not young voters who made things happen. [for Harris]\"Among voters under 35, Harris leads 49-34%, down slightly from Biden's 51-32% lead in June. Harris's big gain has been among voters 35-54, who support her 54-40%, after supporting Trump 44-41% over Biden in June,\" Siena's Greenberg said.\n\nHarris won in a Democratic-majority New York, with 67% of the vote for Trump to 25%.\n\nMore importantly, Harris also leads Trump in the suburbs, 47% to 47%.\n\nStart your day with everything you need to know\n\nMorning Report provides the latest news, videos, photos and more.\n\nThanks for checking in!\n\nThat's a plus for Democrats, considering Trump beat Biden by 13 percentage points in the suburbs in Siena College's June survey.\n\nMost of the key legislative elections are taking place in the suburbs: in Long Island and Westchester counties, Rockland, Putnam and Orange.\n\nThe match was also nearly even in the northern part of the state, with 47% of voters supporting Harris and 45% for Trump.\n\n\"This is better news for Democrats running in a marginal district,\" Greenberg said.\n\nHarris is supported by 86% of Democrats, compared to 75% for Biden in June. AFP via Getty Images\n\nIn the House of Representatives elections, 47% of suburban voters support a Democratic candidate, while 44% support a Republican candidate - a result too close to predict.\n\nSimilarly, 44% of upstate residents support a Democrat for Congress and 42% a Republican, a tie.\n\nFifty-three percent of voters in blue-leaning New York state had a favorable view of Harris, compared with 43% who did not.\n\nIn contrast, 59% of respondents had an unfavorable opinion of New Yorker Trump, while 39% had a favorable opinion.\n\nMost voters said this presidential race was the most important of their lives: 79% of Democrats, 77% of Republicans and 65% of independents.\n\nIn another key race, Democratic incumbent Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, who is running for a third full six-year term, leads her Republican opponent Mike Sapraicone, a retired NYPD detective, by 23 points -- 56 percent to 33 percent.\n\n\"With just 13 weeks until Election Day, Gillibrand is in a strong position to win her fourth election to the United States Senate,\" Greenberg said.\n\nShe was re-elected in 2018 with a 34-point victory over her then-little-known Republican opponent.\n\nThe survey found that 85% of voters did not know Sapraicone well enough to have an opinion, while 27% had no opinion on Gillibrand, who has been in power for 15 years.\n\nThe Siena College poll was conducted July 28 through Aug. 1 among 1,199 likely voters, via smartphones and landlines. {"uri": "8261498546", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "09:25:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T09:25:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T09:25:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/kamala-harris-polling-boost-naming-her-vp-1935040", "title": "Kamala Harris gets polling boost before naming her VP", "body": "The poll of 1,510 likely voters in the United States, conducted between August 2 and 4, found 48 percent would vote for Harris if an election were held \"today,\" versus 45 percent for Trump. A further 3 percent said they would back other candidates while 4 percent said they were undecided.\n\nHarris has led Trump in a number of polls since she became the presumptive Democratic presidential candidate shortly after President Joe Biden dropped out of the race and endorsed her on July 21. According to Politico, Harris is expected to announce her running mate at some point on Tuesday after which the pair is to make a joint appearance at a rally in Philadelphia in the evening.\n\nThe SurveyUSA poll gave Trump a 13-point lead among white voters, while Harris had a 53-point lead with Black voters and a 19-point lead with Latino and Asian voters. The Republican nominee polled best with voters aged 18-34, where he led by 4 points. Harris had a 10-point lead among voters aged 35-49, a 1-point advantage with voters aged 50-64 and a 4-point lead with voters 65 and over.\n\nNewsweek contacted representatives of Vice President Kamala Harris and Donald Trump's 2024 presidential election campaign for comment via email on Tuesday outside of regular office hours.\n\nA Morning Consult poll gave Harris a 4-point lead over Trump, with the support of 48 percent of registered voters against 44 percent for the Republican nominee. The survey of 11,265 likely voters, which the pollster said was the \"largest advantage for a Democratic presidential candidate over Trump in nearly a year,\" took place between August 2 and 4.\n\nA survey of 3,000 registered voters conducted by RMG Research between July 29 and 31 gave Harris a 5-point lead over Trump, with the support of 47 percent of those surveyed against 42 percent.\n\nOn August 5, Harris held a 2-point lead over Trump according to an analysis of recent polls conducted by polling aggregation website FiveThirtyEight, which placed her on 45.5 percent against 43.5 percent for the former president. The study found another 5.5 percent supported Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the former Democrat turned independent candidate.\n\nThe Silver Bulletin presidential election forecast, which was released on August 2, compiled polling averages from recent surveys in a number of key swing states. It found Harris led Trump in Pennsylvania by 45.3 to 44.8 percent, Wisconsin by 46 to 44.8 percent and Michigan at 45.2 versus 42.8 percent.\n\nHowever, Trump led in Georgia 46.3 to 44.8 percent, North Carolina 46.7 to 44.7 percent, Arizona 46.3 to 43.8 percent and Nevada 43.9 to 42.6 percent.\n\nOn Monday, Reuters reported Harris had narrowed her vice presidential shortlist down to two, with the finalists being Governors Tim Walz of Minnesota and Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania. Other candidates who were reportedly under consideration included Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg and Senator Mark Kelly from Arizona.\n\nIn a message directed to supporters on Monday, Harris insisted she had yet to make a final decision. Providing a link where people could sign up for the announcement the Democratic nominee said: \"I know many of you are eager to find out who I will be selecting to join me on the campaign trail, and hopefully in the White House, as my Vice President.\n\n\"Though I have not made my decision yet, it is important to me that grassroots supporters -- like you -- have direct updates about the state of {"uri": "8260855132", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "23:20:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T23:20:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T23:20:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://gvwire.com/2024/08/05/harris-gains-ground-on-trump-leading-him-in-some-polls/", "title": "Harris Gains Big Ground on Trump, Leads Him in Some Polls", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris has made significant gains against former President Donald Trump in the presidential race, according to several recent polls, Forbes reports.\n\nSince taking over the campaign from Joe Biden, Harris now leads Trump by four points in the latest Morning Consult survey, marking a high point for a Democratic candidate in nearly a year.\n\nIn the Morning Consult poll, Harris holds a 48% to 44% lead over Trump, with 5% of registered voters preferring another candidate and 4% undecided. This is the third consecutive week the poll has shown Harris ahead of Trump.\n\nA CBS News poll shows Harris with a one-point national lead over Trump, boosted by increased support from younger and Black voters and women who believe Harris will prioritize their interests. The poll, conducted from July 30 to Aug. 2, also indicates that Harris and Trump are tied in seven key battleground states, including Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin.\n\nRelated Story: Poll: Harris Pulls Ahead of Trump in Six Swing States\n\nDespite leading Harris in at least eight other polls since Biden's withdrawal, Trump has seen his lead narrow. Most surveys show Harris improving her standing compared to Biden, with her approval rating rising since announcing her candidacy. In a five-way race with third-party candidates, Harris leads Trump 46% to 44%, according to the Economist/YouGov poll.\n\nRealClearPolitics' latest polling average shows Trump with a narrow 0.7-point lead over Harris, while FiveThirtyEight's average gives Harris a 1.9-point advantage.\n\nThe Democratic Party has rallied around Harris, with nearly 80% of Democratic voters expressing support for her candidacy, according to a New York Times/Siena survey. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9792426", "eventUri": "eng-9792426", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-30", "dateEnd": "2024-08-02", "textStart": 806, "textEnd": 823}], "sentiment": 0.1372549019607843, "wgt": 186, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8263361314", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "10:46:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T10:46:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T10:45:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/kamala-harris-battleground-state-chances-donald-trump-1935651", "title": "Kamala Harris' chances of beating Donald Trump in each battleground state", "body": "She has pulled ahead in several battleground states as well as nationally. But before Biden stepped aside, Donald Trump led polling in every one of these key states.\n\nSo how do the polls currently view Harris' chances of winning the battleground states that will decide the election? Looking at poll trends, state by state, the final analysis shows she has made progress, but will that be enough?\n\nHarris is the presumptive Democratic nominee, with all her major potential rivals in the party having endorsed her. She and her running mate Tim Walz are set to be confirmed at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago later this month.\n\nTrump has not led a national poll for over a week, with Harris leading by between 1 and 5 points in 17 of the 18 most recent surveys (one national survey has them tied).\n\nBut as with Trump in 2016 and George W. Bush in 2000, a candidate can lose the popular vote nationally and still win the White House. While polling in most of the 50 states strongly indicate which candidate will win there in November, neither candidate currently strongly leads in enough states to win the election.\n\nA handful of states remain as tossups and so it is these states that will effectively decide the outcome of the race.\n\nNewsweek reached out to Harris and Trumps' campaigns for comment outside of regular working hours.\n\nHere's how Harris currently fares against Trump in key swing states.\n\nArizona\n\nIn Arizona, Trump has led in five of the eight most recent polls. However the three polls where Harris does lead indicate a change of political winds in the state since she took over. Trump had beaten Biden in every Arizona poll since May, sometimes by margins of 10 to 15 points.\n\nThe latest survey, by Redfield and Wilton Strategies for The Telegraph, between July 31 and August 3, of 567 likely voters, found Harris leading 44 percent to Trump's 43 percent.\n\nAnother poll taken by Public Policy Polling and funded by the Democrat-aligned Progress Action Fund, surveyed 618 registered voters between July 29 and 30 and shows Trump leading 49 percent to Harris' 47 percent.\n\nPolling aggregators have Trump slightly in the lead on average. FiveThirtyEight has Trump on 45.4 percent and Harris on 44.1. RaceToTheWhiteHouse has Trump on 48.8 and Harris on 46.7.\n\nGeorgia\n\nIn Georgia, Trump has led in eight of the eleven most recent polls. Harris leads in one Democrat-funded poll and two more have the candidates tied.\n\nHowever, even more extremely than in Arizona, Harris pulling even or ahead in Georgia shows a massive surge of support toward the Democrats. Trump had beaten Biden in every Georgia poll since May 2023, often by margins of 6 to 10 points.\n\nThe latest survey, by Redfield and Wilton Strategies for The Telegraph, between July 31 and August 3, of 1128 likely voters, found Trump leading 46 percent to Harris's 44 percent.\n\nAnother poll taken by Public Policy Polling and funded by the Democrat-aligned Progress Action Fund, surveyed 662 registered voters between July 29 and 30 and showed Harris leading 48 percent to Trump's 47 percent.\n\nPolling aggregators have Trump slightly in the lead on average. FiveThirtyEight has Trump on 45.9 percent and Harris on 44.8. RaceToTheWhiteHouse has Trump on 48.2 and Harris on 47.5.\n\nMichigan\n\nRecent polls of Michigan voters do not paint a clear picture of which direction the election will go. Trump leads in six of the twelve most recent polls, while the candidates pull even in four and in two polls, which were conducted by the same firm, Harris has a lead of over 10 points, indicating these results may be outliers.\n\nThe latest survey, by Redfield and Wilton Strategies for The Telegraph, between July 31 and August 3, of 771 likely voters, found Trump leading 42 percent to Harris' 41 percent.\n\nAnother poll taken by Public Opinion Strategies, surveyed 400 likely voters between July 23 and 29 and showed Harris and Trump even on 45 percent each.\n\nPolling aggregators have Harris slightly in the lead on average. FiveThirtyEight has Harris on 44.6 percent and Trump on 43.0. RaceToTheWhiteHouse has Harris on 49.2 percent and Trump on 46.5.\n\nNevada\n\nIn Nevada, Trump has led in three of the six most recent polls. Harris leads in one and they are tied in two. However, similar to Arizona and Georgia, Biden had been losing Nevada by a significant margin. Trump led in every poll in the state since the first one held this election cycle, in February. The poll where Harris leads and the two where they pull even suggest a much tighter race than was expected under Biden.\n\nThe latest survey, by Redfield and Wilton Strategies for The Telegraph, between July 31 and August 3, of 470 likely voters, found Harris and Trump even on 40 per cent each.\n\nAnother poll taken by Public Opinion Strategies, surveyed 400 likely voters between July 23 and 29 and found Trump leading 46 percent to Harris' 45 percent.\n\nPolling aggregator RaceToTheWhiteHouse has Harris slightly in the lead on average, with 46.1 percent while Trump has 45.3 percent. FiveThirtyEight has not published an aggregate for Nevada since Biden dropped out.\n\nNorth Carolina\n\nTrump leads Harris in every recent poll in North Carolina; he also led Biden in every poll before Biden stepped aside. However, the margin is drawing closer. The five polls conducted since July 19 have Trump ahead of Harris by between 1 and 4 points. Against Biden, Trump was leading by between 2 and 9 points.\n\nPennsylvania\n\nPennsylvania is currently the closest race of the 50 states. Trump has led in five of the ten most recent polls, Harris has led in three, and they are tied in two.\n\nThe latest survey, by Redfield and Wilton Strategies for The Telegraph, between July 31 and August 3, of 743 likely voters, found Trump leading Harris 46 percent to Harris' 44 percent.\n\nAnother poll taken by Public Opinion Strategies, surveyed 400 likely voters between July 23 and 29 and found Harris leading 48 percent to Trump's 45 percent.\n\nPolling aggregators have Harris very slightly in the lead on average, in both cases by less than one percent. FiveThirtyEight has Harris on 45.3 percent and Trump on 44.5. RaceToTheWhiteHouse has Harris on 48 percent and Trump on 47.9.\n\nBefore Biden dropped out, Trump had led in every Pennsylvania poll since the June 27 debate in Atlanta, where Biden's performance was widely criticized.\n\nWisconsin\n\nWisconsin is another close race. Harris has led in four of the nine most recent polls, Trump has led in two, and they are tied in three.\n\nThe latest survey, by Redfield and Wilton Strategies for The Telegraph, between July 31 and August 3, of 597 likely voters, found the candidates tied on 43 percent each.\n\nAnother poll taken by Public Opinion Strategies, surveyed 400 likely voters between July 23 and 29 and found Harris leading 48 percent to Trump's 46 percent.\n\nPolling aggregators have Harris very slightly in the lead on average. FiveThirtyEight has Harris on 45.8 percent and Trump on 44.4. RaceToTheWhiteHouse has Harris on 49.5 percent and Trump on 47.7.\n\nThe final analysis\n\nUsing current polling numbers, Harris leads in four of the seven most competitive swing states, while Trump leads in three. According to the Electoral College polling map produced by RaceToTheWhiteHouse, if the election were exactly matched current polling in each state, Harris would win the Electoral College with 276 "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.ccenterdispatch.com/news/national/article_ea54c726-e945-542d-954d-b52b48b144ae.html", "title": "Harris picks Minnesota governor Walz as running mate", "body": "Kamala Harris has picked Minnesota Governor Tim Walz as her running mate\n\nKamala Harris picked Tim Walz as her running mate Tuesday, opting for the Minnesota governor as the partner most likely to complement her in a historic -- and bruising -- bid for the White House.\n\nWalz had been on a shortlist with a string of other Democratic figures seen as broadening Harris's appeal as she sprints into the contest against Donald Trump.\n\nAiming to make history as the first woman president, Harris -- already a trailblazer as the first female and first Black and South Asian vice president -- has little time before Election Day on November 5.\n\nThe choice was first reported by CNN early Tuesday morning.\n\nExpectations had always been that Harris would pick a white man to balance the ticket -- and the kind of Democrat who can help counter attacks from Republicans that she is too far to the left.\n\nWalz fits that description as a 60-year-old Midwesterner with a folksy manner from a state that could be light years from the coastal elites of California, where Harris comes from, or the East Coast.\n\nHe will also appeal to progressives after having championed popular Democratic policies including cannabis legalization and increasing worker protections.\n\nThe duo will hit the campaign trail immediately, launching an intense, five-day swing through battleground states starting Tuesday in the biggest prize, Pennsylvania.\n\nFresh from securing the official Democratic nomination overnight, Harris can now head to the national convention in Chicago in two weeks in total control of her party.\n\nIt has been a remarkable journey for Harris, who only entered the race last month when President Joe Biden withdrew, bowing to mounting concerns over his mental acuity and ability at 81 to serve a second term.\n\nIn a campaign that is barely two weeks old, the 59-year-old former prosecutor has obliterated fundraising records, attracted huge crowds and dominated social media on her way to erasing what had been Trump's growing lead in polls over Biden.\n\nThe latest presidential poll by the University of Massachusetts Amherst released Monday has Harris leading Trump nationally by three points -- 46 percent to 43 percent -- compared to a four-point lead for Trump over Biden in January.\n\n- First major test -\n\nIn the swing states that decide the Electoral College contest in US elections, Harris is neck and neck with Trump, who shocked the world with his 2016 presidential victory but was beaten by Biden in 2020.\n\nPicking a vice presidential running mate was seen as the first big test for Harris in her bid to become the country's chief executive.\n\n\"It tells you about her thought process,\" Amy Walter, a polling expert from Cook Political Report newsletter, told CBS News.\n\nNow, Harris and Walz will face the first test of their ground game as they make the nationwide swing this week from Philadelphia to Wisconsin, Michigan, Arizona and Nevada. Tropical Storm Debby has forced the postponement of a stop in another swing state, Georgia, and according to media reports also North Carolina.\n\nPennsylvania is part of the \"blue wall\" that carried Biden to the White House in 2020, alongside Michigan and Wisconsin. That was one of the main reasons many expected Harris to instead pick that state's governor, Josh Shapiro.\n\nAlso on the vice presidential shortlist had been former astronaut and current senator Mark Kelly, of Arizona, and Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear.\n\nTrump was riding high politically last month after surviving an assassination attempt at a rally, and then using the Republican convention to highlight his image of vigor against the physically frail Biden.\n\nBut with Biden's dramatic exit and Harris's fast start, he is scrambling to recalibrate.\n\nAt a rally last Saturday in Georgia, Trump called Harris a \"Marxist\" and a \"radical left freak,\" claiming she would cause an \"economic crash.\"\n\nThree days earlier, he shocked many when he told an audience of Black journalists that Harris had \"turned Black\" out of political expediency.\n\nWhere Biden often attacked Trump as a threat to democracy, given his unprecedented refusal to accept his loss in 2020, Harris's team has honed a sharper -- more meme-friendly -- line built around branding Trump and his vice presidential pick J.D. Vance \"weird.\"\n\nOn Saturday, the Harris campaign said Trump was \"scared\" to debate her after he turned down a previously scheduled televised debate on ABC, while saying he'd be ready to debate her on Fox News -- a network that has for years given him support.\n\nsms-ft/nro", "source": {"uri": "ccenterdispatch.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Clay Center Dispatch On-Line"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-08-446082590", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "19:00:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T19:00:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T18:42:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/4814099-harris-gains-momentum-presidential-race/", "title": "Harris momentum builds in polls", "body": "A presidential race that at one point seemed like it was becoming former President Donald Trump's to lose increasingly looks like a tossup as Vice President Kamala Harris gains momentum and a new running mate.\n\nThe extent to which Harris's pick of Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz (D) helps her is up in the air, but there's no question the vice president has been riding an upward swing in the polls since President Biden ended his reelection bid late last month and endorsed her.\n\nHarris and Trump are basically tied in the national polling average tracked by The Hill/Decision Desk HQ, with Trump winning 47.1 percent in the average of polls, and Harris at 47 percent. Trump had initially been up by more than 6 points when Harris first declared her candidacy following Biden's decision to leave the race.\n\nThe Hill/Decision Desk HQ model polling average isn't the only place giving Harris and Democrats new hope, either.\n\nHarris also led Trump in pollster Nate Silver's electoral forecast for the first time in recent days after Trump had the advantage against first Biden and then Harris for weeks. The vice president's chance of winning the election also surpassed Trump's.\n\nSilver last week declared the race a \"toss-up,\" the same place it is considered now. He had previously seen Trump as a favorite against Biden because of the incumbent's poorer performance in battleground states even before the debate.\n\nDDHQ has tracked a shift in the Democrats' favor in nine of 10 key states in addition to the national polling. The largest shift in the polling average from before Biden dropped out has been in North Carolina, which shifted from a Trump lead of 10 points to just 3 points.\n\nDemocrats have long sought a presidential victory in The Tar Heel State, which they've failed to take in a presidential contest since Barack Obama's narrow victory in 2008. A comeback seemed unlikely as Biden faltered, but North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper (D) expressed optimism on Sunday that Harris is capable of flipping the state.\n\nMargins have also narrowed in other states that are more crucial to Democrats winning the White House, though Trump still leads in most of the states likely to determine the outcome.\n\nOnly two polls have been conducted and released in Nevada since Biden dropped out, but together they show Trump with an average lead of 3 points, down from the 9-point lead previously.\n\nEight polls for Pennsylvania and five polls each from Georgia and Michigan have revealed shifts toward Harris of 2 points, 4 points and 3 points, respectively.\n\nHarris has seen improvements in polling in swing states and nationally.\n\nShe led Trump by 1 percentage point nationally and was exactly tied 50-50 in the battleground states in a CBS News/YouGov poll released Sunday. That poll and others have shown an increase in enthusiasm among Democratic voters, with 85 percent now saying they plan to vote this fall compared to 81 percent last month.\n\nA Morning Consult poll released Monday showed Harris leading Trump by 4 points, which is the largest lead for the Democratic presidential candidate in almost a year. Harris also led Trump by 5 points among independents and 9 points among voters 18 to 35 years old, a group that Biden had seemingly been underperforming with in polls.\n\nHarris has performed better than Biden in polls that include independent candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr.\n\nTrump led Biden on average by varying but small margins in three-way contests that included Kennedy, but Harris has held a narrow 1.5-point lead in that scenario in the average from DDHQ and The Hill. FiveThirtyEight's polling average shows her with a similar lead.\n\nAll of the polls point to a tight race, suggesting both candidates will have to work hard to turn out their supporters.\n\nAfter Harris became a candidate, Trump pollster Tony Fabrizio argued in a memo that Harris will experience a honeymoon period of positive headlines that will raise her numbers and possibly even put her ahead of Trump but that the change would be temporary.\n\nThe question now is if and when that honeymoon will end, and what the numbers will look like as the candidates sprint toward the fall.", "source": {"uri": "thehill.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hill"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jared_gans@thehill.com", "name": "Jared Gans", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": {"uri": "8261517907", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "09:40:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T09:40:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T09:37:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/kamala-harris-donald-trump-national-polls-1935022", "title": "Kamala Harris now leads in all major polling averages", "body": "Since launching her campaign in recent weeks, Harris has seen largely positive poll results. Overall, the polls indicate she has closed the gap on Trump compared to when President Joe Biden, who dropped out of the race on July 21, was on the ticket.\n\nAccording to RealClearPolitics, Harris is leading her Republican opponent by a marginal 0.2 points -- 47 percent to his 46.8 percent. It is the first time a Democrat has led in the race, according to the aggregator.\n\nThe vice president is also leading Trump by a 0.2 percent margin in VoteHub's poll aggregator, which shows her with 46.4 percent of the vote to his 46.2 percent.\n\nMeanwhile, The Economist's poll aggregator shows Harris with 47 percent to the former president's 46 percent, while Race to the White House shows the vice president with 47.6 percent to Trump's 46.3 percent.\n\nAggregator FiveThirtyEight and pollster Nate Silver show that Harris' lead is larger.\n\nAccording to FiveThirtyEight, Harris is now 2 points ahead of Trump, with 45.5 percent to his 43.5 percent. Similarly, Silver's model, which compiles the results of statewide polls and weights them based on reliability, shows Harris leading Trump with 45.7 percent to his 43.8 percent.\n\nNewsweek has contacted the Trump and Harris campaigns via email for comment.\n\nSilver's model had shown Trump polling ahead of the Democratic candidate for most of July -- including during the weeks immediately after Biden dropped out of the race, with Harris first leading Trump on July 31, according to data published on Sunday.\n\nDespite Harris' lead, the race is still close, according to Silver, who said Harris had a 50.5 percent chance of winning the Electoral College in November and a 66 percent chance of winning the popular vote.\n\nLast week, Silver gave Trump a 54.9 percent chance of winning the Electoral College. Against Biden, his model had given Trump a 73 percent chance to win the election.\n\nRace to the White House also shows Harris winning the Electoral College, as she leads Trump with 275 electoral votes to his 262. Last week, the results were flipped, with the aggregator showing the Democratic candidate with 256 electoral votes to the GOP's 275.\n\nA new CBS News/YouGov poll conducted between July 30 and August 2 found the two candidates tied in key battleground states and Harris leading Trump nationally by 1 point.\n\nThe poll surveyed 3,102 registered voters and had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.1 percentage points.\n\nTrump's campaign dismissed the CBS News/YouGov poll on Sunday, accusing it of putting \"a finger on the scale of polling to inflate results\" for Harris.", "source": {"uri": running mate", "body": "Kamala Harris, United States vice president and Democratic Party presidential hopeful, on Tuesday, picked Tim Walz as her running mate.\n\nWalz, according to reports, had been on a shortlist with a string of other Democratic figures seen as broadening Harris's appeal as she sprints into the contest against Donald Trump.\n\nHarris who is aiming to make history as the first woman president, already a trailblazer as the first female and first Black and South Asian vice president.\n\nShe has little time before Election Day on November 5.\n\nThe choice was first reported by CNN early Tuesday morning.\n\nExpectations had always been that Harris would pick a white man to balance the ticket - and the kind of Democrat who can help counter attacks from Republicans that she is too far to the left.\n\nWalz fits that description as a 60-year-old Midwesterner with a folksy manner from a state that could be light years from the coastal elites of California, where Harris comes from, or the East Coast.\n\nHe will also appeal to progressives after having championed popular Democratic policies including cannabis legalization and increasing worker protections.\n\nThe duo will hit the campaign trail immediately, launching an intense, five-day swing through battleground states starting Tuesday in the biggest prize, Pennsylvania.\n\nFresh from securing the official Democratic nomination overnight, Harris can now head to the national convention in Chicago in two weeks in total control of her party.\n\nIt has been a remarkable journey for Harris, who only entered the race last month when President Joe Biden withdrew, bowing to mounting concerns over his mental acuity and ability at 81 to serve a second term.\n\nIn a campaign that is barely two weeks old, the 59-year-old former prosecutor has obliterated fundraising records, attracted huge crowds and dominated social media on her way to erasing what had been Trump's growing lead in polls over Biden.\n\nThe latest presidential poll by the University of Massachusetts Amherst released Monday has Harris leading Trump nationally by three points -- 46 percent to 43 percent -- compared to a four-point lead for Trump over Biden in January.\n\nIn the swing states that decide the Electoral College contest in US elections, Harris is neck and neck with Trump, who shocked the world with his 2016 presidential victory but was beaten by Biden in 2020.\n\nPicking a vice presidential running mate was seen as the first big test for Harris in her bid to become the country's chief executive.\n\n\"It tells you about her thought process,\" Amy Walter, a polling expert from Cook Political Report newsletter, told CBS News.\n\nNow, Harris and Walz will face the first test of their ground game as they make the nationwide swing this week from Philadelphia to Wisconsin, Michigan, Arizona and Nevada. Tropical Storm Debby has forced the postponement of a stop in another swing state, Georgia, and according to media reports also North Carolina.\n\nPennsylvania is part of the \"blue wall\" that carried Biden to the White House in 2020, alongside Michigan and Wisconsin. That was one of the main reasons many expected Harris to instead pick that state's governor, Josh Shapiro.\n\nAlso on the vice presidential shortlist had been former astronaut and current senator Mark Kelly, of Arizona, and Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear.\n\nTrump was riding high politically last month after surviving an assassination attempt at a rally, and then using the Republican convention to highlight his image of vigor against the physically frail Biden.\n\nBut with Biden's dramatic exit and Harris's fast start, he is scrambling to recalibrate.\n\nAt a rally last Saturday in Georgia, Trump called Harris a \"Marxist\" and a \"radical left freak,\" claiming she would cause an \"economic crash.\"\n\nThree days earlier, he shocked many when he told an audience of Black journalists that Harris had \"turned Black\" out of political expediency.\n\nWhere Biden often attacked Trump as a threat to democracy, given his unprecedented refusal to accept his loss in 2020, Harris's team has honed a sharper -- more meme-friendly -- line built around branding Trump and his vice presidential pick J.D. Vance \"weird.\"\n\nOn Saturday, the Harris campaign said Trump was \"scared\" to debate her after he turned down a previously scheduled televised debate on ABC, while saying he'd be ready to debate {"uri": "8260805926", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "22:18:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T22:18:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T22:17:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://townhall.com/tipsheet/rebeccadowns/2024/08/05/what-do-we-make-of-this-poll-showing-kamala-harris-ahead-n2642985", "title": "What Do We Make of This Poll Showing Kamala Harris Ahead?", "body": "Now that Democrats have Vice President Kamala Harris as their presumptive nominee for president, there's plenty of supposed excitement and enthusiasm from the base. The mainstream media has certainly done their part by trying to hide or even lie about her far-left record, and she hasn't even had to answer to anything through press conferences. Especially with President Joe Biden pretty much being MIA even before he dropped out of the presidential race on July 21, in that context, can we really trust polls showing Harris ahead?\n\nOn Sunday, CBS News/YouGov released a poll showing Harris tied with former and potentially future President Donald Trump in the battleground states, at 50 percent. She has a slight lead nationally, however, at 50-49 percent. The battleground states included Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, North Carolina, Nevada, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin.\n\nThe results in the battleground states among likely voters look questionable, especially regarding how Trump is only up +3 in Georgia and North Carolina, 50-47 percent against Harris. This poll also shows Harris up +2 in Nevada, 50-48 percent, which has been one of Trump's best states, at least when he was running against Biden.\n\nThe result was something CBS News Poll highlighted, pointing out how Biden never led Trump in such polls.\n\nA headline from CBS News highlighted how Democrats are excited when it comes to their new presumptive nominee. \"Boosts in Democratic excitement help Harris reset the race against Trump -- CBS News poll,\" it read.\n\nAs that piece began by mentioning:\n\nBoosted by Democrats, younger and Black voters becoming more engaged and likely to vote, and by women decidedly thinking she'd favor their interests more, Vice President Kamala Harris has reset the 2024 presidential race.\n\nShe has a 1-point edge nationally -- something President Biden never had (he was down by 5 points when he left the race) -- and Harris and former President Donald Trump are tied across the collective battleground states.\n\nFor all of this talk about black voters being \"becoming more engaged and likely to vote,\" it's worth noting that buried in the methodology section at the end of the write-up is a note about how such respondents are oversampled.\n\nWhile the poll from July 18 showed that 81 percent of registered voters who are Democrats will \"definitely\" vote, that number is now at 85 percent. Republicans, meanwhile, saw a slight decrease. While 90 percent of registered voters who are Republicans said they'll \"definitely\" vote, that number is now at 88 percent.\n\nWith leaners included, Republicans look to be supporting Trump about the same amount that Democrats are supporting Harris, at 97 percent and 96 percent, respectively.\n\nNow is not the time to get complacent, but rather to highlight the records involved. GovTrack may have deleted the web page showing as much, but that doesn't change how Harris was the most liberal senator in 2019, one of the least bipartisan ones, and one of the ones most frequently absent.\n\nThe polling tellingly reveals that a plurality of overall voters (43 percent), Democrats (48 percent), and Independents (43 percent), as well as most other demographics, say they know \"some\" about Harris. This is definitely an opportunity for Republicans and the Trump-Vance campaign. That 15 percent of overall voters consider her to be \"moderate\" is also something to correct.\n\n\"Voters do see her as somewhat or very liberal. (The more conservative one is, the more likely they are to view her as very liberal.) Then again, voters see Trump as very or somewhat conservative -- and so that choice is more polarized than the electorate as a whole,\" the poll's write-up highlighted.\n\nUnder a subheading of \"Enthusiasm and core Democratic groups,\" the poll's write-up speaks further to enthusiasm as well:\n\nMost Democratic voters, and nearly half of voters overall, say that Harris as the Democratic nominee makes them feel more motivated to vote. (There is some countering effect, too: about a third of Trump voters are also more motivated to vote now that Harris is the nominee.)\n\nIt's not just that Democrats are more excited, but also on a number of candidate qualities they feel they've gotten a candidate that can match up more closely with Trump.\n\nHarris has an advantage over Trump on being seen as having the mental and cognitive health to serve, which was a critical deficit for Mr. Biden.\n\nAcross the wider set of voters, she's ahead of Trump on being energetic and focused (two qualities Mr. Biden trailed Trump badly on). She's even with Trump on perceived competence, and closer than Mr. Biden was on being tough and effective.\n\nFor all of these attributes supposedly going in Harris' favor, 56 percent say they would not describe her as \"effective,\" and 52 percent say they would not describe her as \"tough.\" In contrast, 54 percent would describe Trump as \"effective,\" while 66 percent say they would describe him as \"tough.\"\n\nSince the poll was conducted and released, issues about the economy have become that much more prevalent.\n\nA plurality of voters, at 33 percent, say the economy is \"very bad.\" A plurality of voters, at 35 percent, also similarly say that things are going \"very badly\" when asked how they think \"generally speaking\" how do they feel \"things in America today are going[?]\"\n\nThe poll also showed that 26 percent of voters each say they expect the economy next year to be \"growing, but not booming\" or \"holding steady.\" Twenty-three percent expect the economy to be \"in recession.\"\n\nOn Friday, the jobs report for July was released, showing there were far fewer jobs than expected, with unemployment rising to 4.3 percent. The stock market is also burning.\n\nA plurality of voters, at 44 percent, believe they will be \"financially worse off\" if Harris wins, while 31 percent say her policies will make their situation will \"stay about the same,\" and just 25 percent say they will be \"financially better off.\"\n\nA plurality of voters, 45 percent, however, believe that they will be \"financially better off\" under Trump's policies if he wins.\n\nAnother top issue for voters is the border crisis. A majority of voters, 52 percent, believe that Harris' policies will \"increase the number of migrants trying to cross the border.\" A plurality of her fellow Democrats, at 47 percent, believe her policies \"won't have an effect.\"\n\nIn stark contrast, 72 percent of overall voters believe that Trump's policies will \"decrease the number of migrants trying to cross the border,\" with a majority of every single demographic polled saying so. Even 53 percent of Democrats believe that will be the case.\n\n\"But to Trump's advantage, some critical things have not changed: he keeps his sizable lead on voters saying they'll be financially better off with him and that his policies would decrease migrants at the border,\" the poll's write-up highlights, which is indeed a signficant advantage that Trump still enjoys.\n\nThe poll was conducted with 3,102 registered voters from July 30-August 2 with a margin of error of plus or minus 2.1 percentage points. The job report was released on the last day that the poll was conducted.\n\nAlthough he emphasized the enthusiasm of voters for Harris, Anthony Salvanto, the executive director of elections and surveys, also spoke to such benefits for Trump while appearing on Sunday's episode of \"Face the Nation.\"\n\nSalvanto highlighted how \"some things in this race have not changed,\" specifically in that \"the idea that you would be better off financially if Trump were elected, Trump still has a big advantage over now Kamala Harris on that. And the idea that his policies would slow or decrease the number of migrants trying to cross the border, that, he still has an edge on.\"\n\nOn Sunday, when the poll came out, the Trump-Vance campaign sent out a statement from Brian Hughes, senior advisor.\n\n\"The Fake News Media continue to help dangerously liberal Kamala hide her record of economic failure and soft-on crime policies. Now, as this analysis shows they'll even put a finger on the scale of polling to inflate results for her. This analysis is why the American people are seeing through it and will not allow this national gaslighting campaign to win. Despite this manipulated result, from CBS/YouGov it's worth noting that in July and August of 2020, their data showed Biden leading by 10 nationally, reflecting a net positive movement of almost +10 to President Trump this election cycle,\" he noted in a statement about the poll.", "source": {"uri": "townhall.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Townhall"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8262613239", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "00:02:22", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T00:02:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T00:01:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.citizen.co.za/news/news-world/harris-picks-minnesota-governor-walz-as-running-mate/", "title": "Harris picks Minnesota governor Walz as running mate | The Citizen", "body": "Kamala Harris picked Tim Walz as her running mate Tuesday, opting for the Minnesota governor as the partner most likely to complement her in a historic -- and bruising -- bid for the White House.\n\nWalz had been on a shortlist with a string of other Democratic figures seen as broadening Harris's appeal as she sprints into the contest against Donald Trump.\n\nAiming to make history as the first woman president, Harris -- already a trailblazer as the first female and first Black and South Asian vice president -- has little time before Election Day on November 5.\n\nALSO READ: Harris campaign raises hulking $310m in July\n\nThe choice was first reported by CNN early Tuesday morning.\n\nExpectations had always been that Harris would pick a white man to balance the ticket -- and the kind of Democrat who can help counter attacks from Republicans that she is too far to the left.\n\nWalz fits that description as a 60-year-old Midwesterner with a folksy manner from a state that could be light years from the coastal elites of California, where Harris comes from, or the East Coast.\n\nHe will also appeal to progressives after having championed popular Democratic policies including cannabis legalization and increasing worker protections.\n\nThe duo will hit the campaign trail immediately, launching an intense, five-day swing through battleground states starting Tuesday in the biggest prize, Pennsylvania.\n\nFresh from securing the official Democratic nomination overnight, Harris can now head to the national convention in Chicago in two weeks in total control of her party.\n\nIt has been a remarkable journey for Harris, who only entered the race last month when President Joe Biden withdrew, bowing to mounting concerns over his mental acuity and ability at 81 to serve a second term.\n\nALSO READ: Obama endorsement adds momentum to Harris White House bid\n\nIn a campaign that is barely two weeks old, the 59-year-old former prosecutor has obliterated fundraising records, attracted huge crowds and dominated social media on her way to erasing what had been Trump's growing lead in polls over Biden.\n\nThe latest presidential poll by the University of Massachusetts Amherst released Monday has Harris leading Trump nationally by three points -- 46 percent to 43 percent -- compared to a four-point lead for Trump over Biden in January.\n\nIn the swing states that decide the Electoral College contest in US elections, Harris is neck and neck with Trump, who shocked the world with his 2016 presidential victory but was beaten by Biden in 2020.\n\nPicking a vice presidential running mate was seen as the first big test for Harris in her bid to become the country's chief executive.\n\n\"It tells you about her thought process,\" Amy Walter, a polling expert from Cook Political Report newsletter, told CBS News.\n\nNow, Harris and Walz will face the first test of their ground game as they make the nationwide swing this week from Philadelphia to Wisconsin, Michigan, Arizona and Nevada. Tropical Storm Debby has forced the postponement of a stop in another swing state, Georgia, and according to media reports also North Carolina.\n\nPennsylvania is part of the \"blue wall\" that carried Biden to the White House in 2020, alongside Michigan and Wisconsin. That was one of the main reasons many expected Harris to instead pick that state's governor, Josh Shapiro.\n\nAlso on the vice presidential shortlist had been former astronaut and current senator Mark Kelly, of Arizona, and Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear.\n\nALSO READ: Republicans must embrace political realities\n\nTrump was riding high politically last month after surviving an assassination attempt at a rally, and then using the Republican convention to highlight his image of vigor against the physically frail Biden.\n\nBut with Biden's dramatic exit and Harris's fast start, he is scrambling to recalibrate.\n\nAt a rally last Saturday in Georgia, Trump called Harris a \"Marxist\" and a \"radical left freak,\" claiming she would cause an \"economic crash.\"\n\nThree days earlier, he shocked many when he told an audience of Black journalists that Harris had \"turned Black\" out of political expediency.\n\nWhere Biden often attacked Trump as a threat to democracy, given his unprecedented refusal to accept his loss in 2020, Harris's team has honed a sharper -- more meme-friendly -- line built around branding Trump and his vice presidential pick J.D. Vance \"weird.\"\n\nOn Saturday, the Harris campaign said Trump was \"scared\" to debate her after he turned down a previously scheduled televised debate on ABC, while saying he'd be ready to debate her on Fox News -- a network that has for years given him support.", "source": {"uri": "citizen.co.za", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Citizen"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8262748304", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "03:00:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T03:00:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T02:57:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2813694/", "title": "Kamala Harris Takes Slight National Lead Over TrumpExBulletin - ExBulletin", "body": "Left: U.S. Vice President Harris arrives for a celebration of NCAA championship teams on the South Lawn of the White House on July 22 in Washington, DC. Right: Republican presidential candidate and former President Donald Trump holds a rally at Van Andel Arena on July 20 in Grand Rapids, Michigan. Andrew Harnik/Getty Images; Bill Pugliano/Getty Images .\n\n. Andrew Harnik/Getty Images; Bill Pugliano/Getty Images\n\nVice President Harris has shaken up the presidential race and now has a 51% to 48% lead over former President Trump, according to the latest NPR/PBS News/Marist poll.\n\nThat result is 4 points higher than the one Harris got just after she entered the race two weeks ago, when President Biden withdrew. Harris also maintains a 3-point lead (48%-45%) when third-party choices are offered.\n\nBlack voters, college-educated white women, and women who identify as politically independent are driving her rise. She is up 20 to 30 points with them than when she took office, which translates into an improvement in the suburbs and with white voters overall.\n\nOn the economy, negative views of Harris don't stick to Biden the way they did to Trump. Trump still enjoys greater confidence on the economy, but only by 3 points over Harris (51%-48%), compared to 9 points over Biden (54%-45%) in June.\n\nHarris also sees improvement in her handling of immigration, though Trump continues to outperform Trump on that issue by 6 points (52%-46%). The best issue Harris leans on is abortion rights. She has a 15-point lead on that issue.\n\nThe survey was conducted Thursday through Sunday, before Harris selected Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as her vice presidential running mate. Marist surveyed 1,613 adults via cellphone, landline and online research panels in English and Spanish. The survey has a margin of error of +/- 3.3 percentage points, meaning the results could be up or down by about 3 percentage points.\n\nWomen, black voters and independents all turned to Harris\n\nBecause of Harris' gains with some groups, she also improved her standing in the suburbs and with white voters overall.\n\nBut the gender gap is now 22 points, which is wider than the gap between Trump and Biden in July. Harris now leads women by 13 points (55%-42%), but trails men by 9 points (54%-45%). Given the margin of error, these results are close to the results of the 2020 presidential election, according to exit polls.\n\nHarris' biggest boost has come from black voters. She went from a 23-point lead over Trump with black voters a few weeks ago, when many voters had swung to the undecided side, to a 54-point lead today. Harris is getting closer to the territory where Democrats need to be with black voters.\n\nSome black voters who seemed to be considering Trump as a candidate have drifted away from him as he lost 10 points with them.\n\nHarris is also now winning votes among independents, something Biden was not. Harris is ahead by 9 points among independents (53%-44%). She was down 14 points among them last month. And in early July, Trump was beating Biden by 4 points among independents.\n\nHarris also made gains with white voters overall. Harris went from 40% with white voters overall to 46% in this poll, which is closer to Biden's, and very high for a Democrat. In fact, no Democrat has scored that high with white voters in a presidential election since Jimmy Carter in 1976. Biden got 41% in 2020, Barack Obama in 2008 won 43%.\n\nThis improvement is driven primarily by white women with college degrees. White voters without college degrees, a key group in Trump's base, largely favor Trump, and their margin remains unchanged. However, two-thirds of white women with college degrees now support Harris, which would be much higher than the percentage who sided with Biden in 2020.\n\nShe is also gaining ground among older voters. Harris leads Trump by 11 points among baby boomers (55%-44%), for example.\n\nLatinos have also shifted toward Harris, with 58% saying they would vote for her now, up from 51% last month. That's still below the 65% Biden won in 2020.\n\nHarris is not yet where she should be with voters under 45. Biden won them in 2020 by 14 points. Harris and Trump are currently tied with this group. However, Harris is doing much better than Biden with this group when it comes to retaining them when third parties are introduced.\n\nBiden, for example, saw a double-digit drop among Gen Z/millennials. Harris, on the other hand, maintained and slightly widened her lead when respondents were given a choice between candidates other than the two chosen by the major parties.\n\nHarris enjoys renewed enthusiasm among key Democratic voter groups\n\nBlack, Latino and young voters say they are more motivated to vote now that Harris is in the race.\n\nBlack, Latino, and Gen Z/millennial voters all jumped by double digits in saying they would definitely vote.\n\nIn July, just 71% of black voters, 68% of Latinos, and 65% of Gen Z/millennials said they would definitely vote, among the lowest rates of any group.\n\nBut now that number is 81% among black voters, 84% among Latinos and 80% among Gen Z/millennials, closer to that of white voters than in previous polls.\n\nThird parties record weakest results in elections\n\nWith Harris in the race, people seem to be moving away from third parties.\n\nAll third-party candidates posted their worst showings since Marist began polling them in April. Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who is running as an independent, is down to 5 percent. Professor Cornel West, also running as an independent, Green Party candidate Jill Stein and Libertarian Chase Oliver are all polling at 1 percent or less.\n\nKennedy still performs better with those who have an unfavorable opinion of Trump and Harris, attracting about a third of those voters.\n\nPeople are divided on who they think will win, but far more think Harris will win than Biden.\n\nLast month, respondents were 20 points more likely to say Trump would beat Biden (59% to 39%). Today, they are split (48% to 48%).\n\nIt is notable that independents went from 58% thinking Trump would win to 52% now thinking Harris would.\n\nPeople are also more satisfied with their choices, although only 47% say they are, compared to 50% who say they are not. In June, there was a 10-point difference between those who were satisfied (42%) and those who were dissatisfied with their choices (52%).\n\nBeing honest and trustworthy is the most important quality for a president\n\nWhile trustworthiness was the most important quality for Democrats and independent voters, a plurality of Republicans said a strong leader was the most important quality to them.\n\nAll signs continue to point to a close election, not only in the presidential election, but also in Congress.\n\nForty-seven percent of Americans want Democrats to take control of Congress, compared to 45% for Republicans. That two-point advantage remains unchanged from June.\n\nDemocrats traditionally need a larger advantage in this score to make significant gains in 2022; when they prevented Republicans from winning a surge of House seats, they had a 4-point advantage in the Marist poll; in 2020, it was 8, but Democrats lost House seats; they were +6 in 2018 and still made significant gains; in 2014, when Republicans gained seats, Republicans were +5 on the question.\n\nCongressional voting and seat counts are not always perfectly correlated, because the most contested seats are in suburban areas of New York, California and around Philadelphia, where Democrats have the advantage in presidential years due to higher turnout among their core constituencies.\n\nBiden's approval is up\n\nNow that Biden has dropped out of the race, his approval ratings are rebounding.\n\nHis approval rating is now 46%, the highest level since February 2023 and up 5 points from last month.\n\nWhat Are The Main {"uri": "8260851653", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "23:16:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T23:16:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T23:15:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/kamala-harris-hits-record-lead-over-trump-new-poll-shows-1934880", "title": "Kamala Harris hits record lead over Trump, new poll shows", "body": "The pollster released its latest survey on the 2024 election on Monday, which found Harris leading Trump 48 percent to 44 percent among registered voters across the country. Morning Consult said the poll was conducted between August 2 and 4 and is based on the responses of 11,265 voters.\n\nMorning Consult said that Harris' 4-point lead is a \"record-high margin in her favor\" and is the \"largest advantage for a Democratic presidential candidate over Trump in nearly a year,\" according to the pollster's election tracking.\n\nOn August 16, 2023, President Joe Biden was found to be ahead of Trump by 5 points among national voters surveyed by Morning Consult. The day before Biden dropped out of the 2024 race, the pollster found him to be 6 points behind the former president (47 percent to 41 percent).\n\nHarris, the presumptive Democratic nominee, also leads Trump by 5 points among independent voters (42 percent to 37 percent) in Monday's poll and was beating the former president by 9 points among young voters between the ages of 18 and 34 (49 percent to 40 percent). The survey has a margin of error of 1 percentage point.\n\nThe vice president was also found to have a higher favorability rating than Trump, with 48 percent of voters saying they have a favorable view of Harris, compared to 47 percent who have an unfavorable view. Trump's favorability rating was in the negatives -- 46 percent of voters said that had a favorable view of the former president, while 52 percent who view him unfavorably.\n\nNewsweek reached out to Harris and Trump's campaigns via email for comment Monday evening.\n\nIn just two weeks since launching her presidential bid, Harris had taken the momentum in the 2024 race. At the end of last week, the vice president was leading in eight national polls. Trump's campaign previously warned its team of a \"Harris honeymoon\" period in the weeks following the vice president's campaign launch.\n\nAggregate polling from The New York Times has Trump still beating Harris by 1 percentage point (48 percent to 47 percent), although the gap between the two candidates has narrowed in recent days. When independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is included in the survey, the Times found that Harris and Trump are tied at 44 percent.\n\nRealClearPolitics also has Trump beating Harris by 0.8 percentage points on average across national polling. On the day that Biden withdrew from the presidential race, Trump was beating the president by just over 3 percentage points, according to RealClearPolitics' polling average.\n\nHarris has also made gains in several pivotal battleground states. Polling averages from the 2024 Silver Bulletin found that the vice president was ahead in Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Michigan as of Friday. Polling averages from the Times found Harris and Trump tied in Wisconsin and Michigan, although the vice president was trailing by 2 percentage points in Pennsylvania as of Monday.", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newsweek"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kaitlin_lewis@newsweek.com", "name": "Kaitlin Lewis", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_poll", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Opinion poll"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morning_Consult", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Morning Consult"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Joe Biden"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)", "type": "org", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Democratic Party (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "2024 United States presidential election"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_voter", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Independent voter"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newsweek", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Newsweek"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Vice President of the United States"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump_2016_presidential_campaign", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Jr.", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Robert F.
