{"uri": "2024-08-445846965", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "14:41:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T14:41:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:16:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/harris-picks-minnesota-governor-walz-as-running-mate/article_51a428fe-ed95-5a4d-9f69-5158a7ac8e67.html", "title": "Harris picks Minnesota governor Walz as running mate", "body": "Kamala Harris has picked Minnesota Governor Tim Walz as her running mate\n\nKamala Harris picked Tim Walz as her running mate Tuesday, opting for the Minnesota governor as the partner most likely to complement her in a historic -- and bruising -- bid for the White House.\n\nWalz had been on a shortlist with a string of other Democratic figures seen as broadening Harris's appeal as she sprints into the contest against Donald Trump.\n\nAiming to make history as the first woman president, Harris -- already a trailblazer as the first female and first Black and South Asian vice president -- has little time before Election Day on November 5.\n\nThe choice was first reported by CNN early Tuesday morning.\n\nExpectations had always been that Harris would pick a white man to balance the ticket -- and the kind of Democrat who can help counter attacks from Republicans that she is too far to the left.\n\nWalz fits that description as a 60-year-old Midwesterner with a folksy manner from a state that could be light years from the coastal elites of California, where Harris comes from, or the East Coast.\n\nHe will also appeal to progressives after having championed popular Democratic policies including cannabis legalization and increasing worker protections.\n\nThe duo will hit the campaign trail immediately, launching an intense, five-day swing through battleground states starting Tuesday in the biggest prize, Pennsylvania.\n\nFresh from securing the official Democratic nomination overnight, Harris can now head to the national convention in Chicago in two weeks in total control of her party.\n\nIt has been a remarkable journey for Harris, who only entered the race last month when President Joe Biden withdrew, bowing to mounting concerns over his mental acuity and ability at 81 to serve a second term.\n\nIn a campaign that is barely two weeks old, the 59-year-old former prosecutor has obliterated fundraising records, attracted huge crowds and dominated social media on her way to erasing what had been Trump's growing lead in polls over Biden.\n\nThe latest presidential poll by the University of Massachusetts Amherst released Monday has Harris leading Trump nationally by three points -- 46 percent to 43 percent -- compared to a four-point lead for Trump over Biden in January.\n\n- First major test -\n\nIn the swing states that decide the Electoral College contest in US elections, Harris is neck and neck with Trump, who shocked the world with his 2016 presidential victory but was beaten by Biden in 2020.\n\nPicking a vice presidential running mate was seen as the first big test for Harris in her bid to become the country's chief executive.\n\n\"It tells you about her thought process,\" Amy Walter, a polling expert from Cook Political Report newsletter, told CBS News.\n\nNow, Harris and Walz will face the first test of their ground game as they make the nationwide swing this week from Philadelphia to Wisconsin, Michigan, Arizona and Nevada. Tropical Storm Debby has forced the postponement of a stop in another swing state, Georgia, and according to media reports also North Carolina.\n\nPennsylvania is part of the \"blue wall\" that carried Biden to the White House in 2020, alongside Michigan and Wisconsin. That was one of the main reasons many expected Harris to instead pick that state's governor, Josh Shapiro.\n\nAlso on the vice presidential shortlist had been former astronaut and current senator Mark Kelly, of Arizona, and Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear.\n\nTrump was riding high politically last month after surviving an assassination attempt at a rally, and then using the Republican convention to highlight his image of vigor against the physically frail Biden.\n\nBut with Biden's dramatic exit and Harris's fast start, he is scrambling to recalibrate.\n\nAt a rally last Saturday in Georgia, Trump called Harris a \"Marxist\" and a \"radical left freak,\" claiming she would cause an \"economic crash.\"\n\nThree days earlier, he shocked many when he told an audience of Black journalists that Harris had \"turned Black\" out of political expediency.\n\nWhere Biden often attacked Trump as a threat to democracy, given his unprecedented refusal to accept his loss in 2020, Harris's team has honed a sharper -- more meme-friendly -- line built around branding Trump and his vice presidential pick J.D. Vance \"weird.\"\n\nOn Saturday, the Harris campaign said Trump was \"scared\" to debate her after he turned down a previously scheduled televised debate on ABC, while saying he'd be ready to debate her on Fox News -- a network that has for years given him support.\n\nsms-ft/nro\n\nMore from this section\n\nEnergyCAP Appoints Shawn Lankton as Chief Executive Officer\n\nReformed Gangster Disciples {"uri": "8261664176", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "11:09:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T11:09:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T11:08:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://neweralive.na/harris-support-grows-against-trump/", "title": "Harris' support grows against Trump", "body": "WASHINGTON - A new poll confirmed on Sunday that Kamala Harris, who is set to name her vice presidential pick imminently, has drawn level with Donald Trump, transforming a White House race that the Republican had been increasingly confident he would win.\n\nAs the 5 November election rapidly approaches, Harris has erased the growing lead that Trump was building before president Joe Biden dropped his re-election bid.\n\nAccording to the CBS News/YouGov poll released on Sunday, Harris has a 1% advantage on Trump nationwide, compared to Trump's previous five-point edge on Biden.\n\nIn the swing states that decide the Electoral College contest in US elections, Harris and Trump, who shocked the world with his 2016 presidential victory but was beaten by Biden in 2020, are equal.\n\nThese are considered good numbers for a Democratic candidate who parachuted into the race only last month, when Biden bowed to mounting concerns over his mental acuity and ability at 81 years old to serve a second term.\n\nBut Harris, who is Biden's vice president and the first Black and South Asian woman ever in the role, is in a sprint to define herself to voters before Trump does.\n\nA big moment in that process will be when Harris announces her choice for running mate in a historic bid to become America's first female president. This could happen as early as Sunday or Monday.\n\nExpectations are that Harris will pick a white man to balance the ticket, and likely a moderate Democrat who would help counterweigh attacks on Harris from Republicans that she is too far to the left.\n\nThe three figures seen as heading the shortlist are Minnesota Governor Tim Walz, Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro, and Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona. They were all visiting Harris in Washington on Sunday, The Washington Post reported.\n\n\"It's her first major decision that she's making as an executive, so it tells you about her thought process,\" Amy Walter, a polling expert from Cook Political Report newsletter, told CBS News.\n\nThe CBS poll, which echoes numerous other surveys indicating rapid gains by Harris, shows Trump is still favoured by voters on the key issue of the economy.\n\nOnly 25% said they expected to be better off financially if Harris wins, compared to 45% who said so about Trump.\n\nHowever, when it comes to trust in the candidates' temperament, the poll shows voters prefer the former California prosecutor to Trump, a convicted felon who has made a career out of publicly insulting those who oppose him, including while president.\n\nThe issue of cognitive health, which used to bedevil Biden, is now a liability for 78-year-old Trump, the poll found. Only 51% of respondents thought Trump is mentally capable for the presidency, compared to 64% for Harris. The Democrats believe that if you \"make this referendum on Trump rather than a referendum on the current state of the economy, then we have a real opportunity to win\".\n\nTrump was riding high politically last month after surviving an assassination attempt at a rally, then using the Republican convention to highlight his image of vigour against the physically frail Biden.\n\nBut with Biden's dramatic exit and Harris's fast start, he's scrambling to recalibrate.\n\nAt a rally on Saturday in the swing state of Georgia, Trump called Harris a \"Marxist\" and a \"radical left freak,\" claiming she would cause an \"economic crash.\" On Wednesday, he shocked many when he told an audience of Black journalists that Harris had \"turned Black\" out of political expediency.\n\nWhere Biden often attacked Trump\n\nas a threat to democracy, given his unprecedented refusal to accept his loss in 2020, Harris's team has honed a sharper, more meme-friendly line built around branding Trump and his vice presidential pick J.D. Harris 2024 Polls: Harris Widens Lead In Latest Surveys", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris continues to cut into former President Donald Trump's lead since becoming the official Democratic presidential nominee, according to several new polls -- with the latest NPR/PBS News/Marist survey showing Harris leading Trump by three points.\n\n0.7. That's how many points Trump leads Harris by in RealClearPolitics' latest polling average. Meanwhile, FiveThirtyEight's weighted average shows Harris with a 1.9-point lead.\n\nThe New York Times/Siena poll found voters are more tuned into the race in the aftermath of the June 27 Biden-Trump debate, which was widely considered disastrous for Biden. Some 64% percent of respondents now say they're paying a lot of attention to the contest, compared to 48% prior to the debate.\n\nHarris leads Trump by one point overall in the seven battleground states likely to decide the election: Michigan, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Nevada, Arizona, North Carolina and Georgia, according to a July 24-28 Bloomberg/Morning Consult poll. Harris is ahead in Michigan, Wisconsin, Arizona and Nevada; Trump leads in Pennsylvania and North Carolina; and the two are tied in Georgia.\n\nDemocrats are far more enthusiastic about Harris than they were about Biden, the Times/Siena survey found, with nearly 80% of voters who lean Democratic saying they would like Harris to be the nominee, compared to 48% of Democrats who said the same about Biden three weeks ago. In a stark contrast with sentiment surrounding Biden's mental fitness, 56% of voters polled by Reuters/Ipsos said Harris was \"mentally sharp and able to deal with challenges,\" compared to 49% who said the same about Trump and 22% for Biden. A 19th News/SurveyMonkey poll found 87% of Americans agreed with Biden's decision to end his campaign, and more Americans think the decision will help the Democratic Party (45%) than the Republican Party (29%). The 19th News survey also showed Americans are split on whether Harris' gender and race will help or hurt her: 31% think being a woman will help her, compared to 33% who think it will hurt her and 34% who see no impact. Respondents were more optimistic that Harris being Black and Indian American will benefit her, with 32% seeing it as helpful compared to 24% seeing it as harmful -- though 41% expected it to have no impact.\n\nTrump campaign pollster Tony Fabrizio predicted a \"short term\" bump in polls for Harris in the coming weeks as her entrance into the race is expected to reenergize Democrats, referring to the anticipated boost as a \"Harris Honeymoon,\" in a memo released shortly after the Reuters/Ipsos poll was made public.\n\nBiden dropped out of the race on July 21 after earlier resisting growing calls from within his own party to end his reelection bid in the wake of his disastrous performance in the June 27 debate. Biden immediately endorsed Harris and she announced plans to seek the nomination. The party has quickly coalesced around her, with all Democratic governors and the majority of Democrats in Congress backing her. She has effectively clinched the Democratic nomination as more than half of all delegates have announced plans to formally vote to nominate her -- something the party is expected to do in the first week of August. An ABC News/Ipsos poll taken July 26-27 found Harris' favorability rating has increased to 43%, from 35% in the groups' previous poll taken July 19-20, while Trump's favorability rating stands at 36% and Biden's is at 37%.\n\nTrump's Lead Over Biden And Harris Jumped After RNC, HarrisX/Forbes Poll Finds (Forbes)", "source": {"uri": "forbes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Forbes"}, "authors": Of 3,092 registered voters contacted, only 35.5% identified themselves as conservatives, compared to 30.3% moderate voters and 30.2% liberal leaners. That's fewer conservatives and moderates than seen in past polls, they say, and unfairly skewed to the left.\n\n\"Without this manipulation, President Trump would be maintaining a 51-49 lead in their August 4 survey,\" the Trump's team said.\n\nBrian Hughes, a Trump campaign senior advisor, said the polls demonstrate that the \"fake news media\" is continuing its crusade to \"help dangerously liberal Kamala hide her record of economic failure and soft on crime policies.\"\n\n\"As this analysis shows they'll even put a finger on the scale of polling to inflate results for her. This analysis is why the American people are seeing through it and will not allow this national gaslighting campaign to win,\" Hughes said.\n\nBut despite the skepticism cast by team Trump, a slew of polls released Monday show similar results.\n\nA survey of 1,326 registered voters conducted by I&I/TIPP shows Harris up by one point in a head-to-head matchup and by two points in a race including third party alternatives, both within the 2.9-point margin of error.\n\nA SurveyUSA poll of 1,500 likely voters found the Vice President leading the 45th President by three points -- outside the 2.4% margin of error -- with 4% of those surveyed reporting they are still undecided.\n\nA Morning Consult poll of 11,265 registered voters released on Monday has Harris up by 4%, well outside that weekly "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://manilastandard.net/news/314481269/harris-picks-minnesota-governor-walz-as-running-mate.html", "title": "Harris picks Minnesota governor Walz as running mate - Manila Standard", "body": "Washington, United States -- Kamala Harris picked Tim Walz as her running mate Tuesday, opting for the Minnesota governor as the partner most likely to complement her in a historic -- and bruising -- bid for the White House.\n\nWalz had been on a shortlist with a string of other Democratic figures seen as broadening Harris's appeal as she sprinted into the contest against Donald Trump.\n\nAiming to make history as the first woman president, Harris -- already a trailblazer as the first female and first Black and South Asian vice president -- has little time before Election Day on November 5.\n\nThe choice was first reported by CNN early Tuesday morning.\n\nExpectations had always been that Harris would pick a white man to balance the ticket -- and the kind of Democrat who can help counter attacks from Republicans that she is too far to the left.\n\nWalz fits that description as a 60-year-old Midwesterner with a folksy manner from a state that could be light years from the coastal elites of California, where Harris comes from, or the East Coast.\n\nHe will also appeal to progressives after having championed popular Democratic policies including cannabis legalization and increasing worker protections.\n\nThe duo will hit the campaign trail immediately, launching an intense, five-day swing through battleground states starting Tuesday in the biggest prize, Pennsylvania.\n\nFresh from securing the official Democratic nomination overnight, Harris can now head to the national convention in Chicago in two weeks in total control of her party.\n\nIt has been a remarkable journey for Harris, who only entered the race last month when President Joe Biden withdrew, bowing to mounting concerns over his mental acuity and ability at 81 to serve a second term.\n\nIn a campaign that is barely two weeks old, the 59-year-old former prosecutor has obliterated fundraising records, attracted huge crowds and dominated social media on her way to erasing what had been Trump's growing lead in polls over Biden.\n\nThe latest presidential poll by the University of Massachusetts Amherst released Monday has Harris leading Trump nationally by three points -- 46 percent to 43 percent -- compared to a four-point lead for Trump over Biden in January.\n\nFirst major test\n\nIn the swing states that decide the Electoral College contest in US elections, Harris is neck and neck with Trump, who shocked the world with his 2016 presidential victory but was beaten by Biden in 2020.\n\nPicking a vice presidential running mate was seen as the first big test for Harris in her bid to become the country's chief executive.\n\n\"It tells you about her thought process,\" Amy Walter, a polling expert from Cook Political Report newsletter, told CBS News.\n\nNow, Harris and Walz will face the first test of their ground game as they make the nationwide swing this week from Philadelphia to Wisconsin, Michigan, Arizona and Nevada. Tropical Storm Debby has forced the postponement of a stop in another swing state, Georgia, and according to media reports also North Carolina.\n\nPennsylvania is part of the \"blue wall\" that carried Biden to the White House in 2020, alongside Michigan and Wisconsin. That was one of the main reasons many expected Harris to instead pick that state's governor, Josh Shapiro.\n\nAlso on the vice presidential shortlist had been former astronaut and current senator Mark Kelly, of Arizona, and Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear.\n\nTrump was riding high politically last month after surviving an assassination attempt at a rally, and then using the Republican convention to highlight his image of vigor against the physically frail Biden.\n\nBut with Biden's dramatic exit and Harris's fast start, he is scrambling to recalibrate.\n\nWhere Biden often attacked Trump as a threat to democracy, given his unprecedented refusal to accept his loss in 2020, Harris's team has honed a sharper -- more meme-friendly -- line built around branding Trump and his vice presidential pick J.D. Vance \"weird.\"\n\nOn Saturday, the Harris campaign said Trump was \"scared\" to debate her after he turned down a previously scheduled televised debate on ABC, while saying he'd be ready to debate {"uri": "8262812123", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "04:10:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T04:10:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T04:08:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://townhall.com/columnists/byronyork/2024/08/07/columnistsbyronyork20240806irrational-exuberance-how-much-has-the-race-changed-n2643059", "title": "'Irrational Exuberance': How Much Has the Race Changed?", "body": "Don't Expect to Get Any Answers from KJP About When Kamala Harris Will Stop Hiding From the Press Rebecca Downs\n\nIt has now been more than two weeks since President Joe Biden dropped out of the race and Vice President Kamala Harris became the Democratic nominee. It's always hard to get a quick handle on public reaction to a huge event like that, but after a couple of weeks, the news has had time to sink in with voters, and it's time to start looking at some new polling.\n\nThe bottom line is that so far, the Biden gambit, the sudden switch forced on the president by powerful Democratic Party insiders, appears to be working. In early July, before the wild series of events that rocked the race -- Trump assassination attempt, GOP convention, JD Vance, Biden withdrawal, rushed delegate vote for Harris -- Trump had a lead of slightly more than 3 points over Biden in the RealClearPolitics average of national polls. Now, two weeks after the Biden/Harris swap, Harris leads Trump by less than a point in the same average.\n\nWhat has happened is precisely what Trump pollster Tony Fabrizio predicted when Biden pulled out. \"We will start to see public polling -- particularly national public polls -- where Harris is gaining on or even leading President Trump,\" Fabrizio wrote in a July 23 memo. \"The Democrats and the MSM will try and tout these polls as proof that the race has changed.\"\n\nThat is the story of the last two weeks and could be the story of the next two weeks before the Democratic convention, which will then add one more week of Harris celebration. Still, Harris is quickly backing away from positions she has held for years, and she has still not answered a single substantive question from any journalist in her two weeks as nominee.\n\nIn a new CBS News/YouGov national poll, Harris has the narrowest possible lead, 50% to 49%, in a head-to-head matchup with Trump. In the last CBS poll, conducted in July during the Republican convention, Trump had a five-point lead over Biden, 52% to 47%.\n\nThere have been other signs that Democrats and some independents are much more enthusiastic about Harris than they were about Biden. Last week, the Harris campaign announced that it raised $310 million in July. That is huge -- a lot more than the $139 million Trump raised, which itself is pretty big.\n\nPlus, there is the obvious fact that Democratic crowds appear more enthusiastic for Harris than they were for Biden. She held her first rally in Atlanta -- no accident, given the huge importance of Georgia in the Electoral College battle -- and she got a big, loud crowd.\n\nAs it turned out, a few days later, Trump had a rally of his own at the same site in Atlanta. He, too, got a big, loud crowd of people happy to be supporting him. Trump has been leading Biden in Georgia for months, and it appears he is still leading Harris, although likely by less.\n\nNevertheless, Trump has clearly had problems re-orienting his campaign. For obvious reasons: He ran against one candidate, Biden, for two years, focusing every thought and attack on Biden, Biden, Biden. Then Democratic insiders pulled off an unprecedented switcheroo, and Trump is no longer facing the opponent he built his campaign around. No candidate and campaign could change tracks without some rough patches.\n\nPlus, Trump is still making some of the same mistakes he has made for years, regardless of his opponent. For example, in the big, enthusiastic Atlanta rally, Trump could not resist bashing Georgia Republican Gov. Brian Kemp, who Trump still holds a grudge over the 2020 vote counting in Georgia, which Biden narrowly won. It made no sense, yet Trump could not stop himself from doing it.\n\nOn the other hand, Harris has had two weeks of the most positive press coverage imaginable, and after that the race is still tied. But is it a new race altogether? Has it been \"reset,\" as some say? Are the issues somehow different? When Fabrizio wrote, \"The Democrats and the MSM will try and tout these polls as proof that the race has changed,\" his next sentence was: \"But the fundamentals of the race stay the same.\"\n\nObviously, Democrats hope that, with the assistance of a willing press, they can make the honeymoon last for the next three months. Maybe they can. But Republicans believe that, given Harris' weaknesses as a candidate and the weaknesses of her record, the current celebration can't continue forever, or even for three months. Fabrizio is probably right that the fundamentals of the race are still the same. It is Donald Trump's job to stay steady, and keep pursuing his three-part message, with one small change: 1) Things were good when I was president. 2) Things went to hell when Harris took office. 3) Elect me, and I'll make them good again. It's a simple message, and we'll see if it can withstand the current wave of Kamalamania.", "source": {"uri": "townhall.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Townhall"}, "authors": [{"uri": "byron_york@townhall.com", "name": "Byron York", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamala_Harris", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kamala Harris"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Joe Biden"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Democratic Party (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden_2020_presidential_campaign", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. {"uri": "2024-08-445774596", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "13:37:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T13:37:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:02:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://timesofmalta.com/article/kamala-harris-picks-minnesota-governor-tim-walz-running-mate.1096387", "title": "Kamala Harris picks Minnesota governor Tim Walz as running mate", "body": "Kamala Harris picked Tim Walz as her running mate Tuesday, opting for the Minnesota governor as the partner most likely to complement her in a historic - and bruising - bid for the White House.\n\nWalz had been on a shortlist with a string of other Democratic figures seen as broadening Harris's appeal as she sprints into the contest against Donald Trump.\n\nAiming to make history as the first woman president, Harris - already a trailblazer as the first female and first Black and South Asian vice president - has little time before Election Day on November 5.\n\nThe choice was first reported by CNN early Tuesday morning.\n\nExpectations had always been that Harris would pick a white man to balance the ticket - and the kind of Democrat who can help counter attacks from Republicans that she is too far to the left.\n\nWalz fits that description as a 60-year-old Midwesterner with a folksy manner from a state that could be light years from the coastal elites of California, where Harris comes from, or the East Coast.\n\nHe will also appeal to progressives after having championed popular Democratic policies including cannabis legalization and increasing worker protections.\n\nThe duo will hit the campaign trail immediately, launching an intense, five-day swing through battleground states starting Tuesday in the biggest prize, Pennsylvania.\n\nFresh from securing the official Democratic nomination overnight, Harris can now head to the national convention in Chicago in two weeks in total control of her party.\n\nIt has been a remarkable journey for Harris, who only entered the race last month when President Joe Biden withdrew, bowing to mounting concerns over his mental acuity and ability at 81 to serve a second term.\n\nIn a campaign that is barely two weeks old, the 59-year-old former prosecutor has obliterated fundraising records, attracted huge crowds and dominated social media on her way to erasing what had been Trump's growing lead in polls over Biden.\n\nThe latest presidential poll by the University of Massachusetts Amherst released Monday has Harris leading Trump nationally by three points - 46 per cent to 43 per cent - compared to a four-point lead for Trump over Biden in January.\n\nFirst major test\n\nIn the swing states that decide the Electoral College contest in US elections, Harris is neck and neck with Trump, who shocked the world with his 2016 presidential victory but was beaten by Biden in 2020.\n\nPicking a vice presidential running mate was seen as the first big test for Harris in her bid to become the country's chief executive.\n\n\"It tells you about her thought process,\" Amy Walter, a polling expert from Cook Political Report newsletter, told CBS News.\n\nNow, Harris and Walz will face the first test of their ground game as they make the nationwide swing this week from Philadelphia to Wisconsin, Michigan, Arizona and Nevada. Tropical Storm Debby has forced the postponement of a stop in another swing state, Georgia, and according to media reports, North Carolina.\n\nPennsylvania is part of the \"blue wall\" that carried Biden to the White House in 2020, alongside Michigan and Wisconsin. That was one of the main reasons many expected Harris to instead pick that state's governor, Josh Shapiro.\n\nAlso on the vice presidential shortlist had been former astronaut and current senator Mark Kelly, of Arizona, and Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear.\n\nTrump was riding high politically last month after surviving an assassination attempt at a rally, and then using the Republican convention to highlight his image of vigor against the physically frail Biden.\n\nBut with Biden's dramatic exit and Harris's fast start, he is scrambling to recalibrate.\n\nAt a rally last Saturday in Georgia, Trump called Harris a \"Marxist\" and a \"radical left freak,\" claiming she would cause an \"economic crash.\"\n\nThree days earlier, he shocked many when he told an audience of Black journalists that Harris had \"turned Black\" out of political expediency.\n\nWhere Biden often attacked Trump as a threat to democracy, given his unprecedented refusal to accept his loss in 2020, Harris's team has honed a sharper - more meme-friendly - line built around branding Trump and his vice presidential pick J.D. Vance \"weird.\"\n\nOn Saturday, the Harris campaign said Trump was \"scared\" to debate her after he turned down a previously scheduled televised debate on ABC, while saying he'd be ready to debate her on Fox News - a network that has for years given him support.", "source": {"uri": "timesofmalta.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "timesofmalta.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8262450346", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "20:56:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T20:56:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T20:55:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://cbs12.com/news/beyond-the-podium/90-days-out-who-can-win-the-most-enthusiasm-this-election-donald-trump-kamala-harris-president-vp-vance-walz-2024-voters-poll-economy-biden-immigration", "title": "90 days out, who can win the most enthusiasm this election?", "body": "HUNT VALLEY, Md. (TND) -- We are officially 90 days out from an unprecedented presidential election in the U.S.\n\nWe've got a former president who's trying to redeem himself after losing his first bid for re-election four years ago -- who is also a convicted felon -- up against the current vice president, who was nominated after the incumbent president dropped out of the race.\n\nThe unusual arrangement has cast aside a long-expected Trump-Biden rematch for a short term race to the finish line.\n\nWith enthusiasm for Vice President Kamala Harris atop the Democratic ticket suddenly surging, she's riding a wave of excitement similar to the one former President Donald Trump rode to the White House in 2016.\n\nAnd with few opportunities to nail down Harris on her policy positions ahead of Election Day, Americans may find themselves voting for the candidate whose personality most resonates with them.\n\nWe know Trump's top priorities: tax cuts, tariffs, immigration crackdown, border security, crime crackdown, relaxed environmental regulations, states' rights, and an \"America First\" foreign policy.\n\nAnd we already know Harris', although her presidential campaign began just roughly 100 days before game time: climate action, tax the rich, fund public education, support foreign allies, restore reproductive rights, affordable health care, police reform, and a legal pathway to citizenship for immigrants.\n\nWe'll hear both candidates tout these priorities, but probably not as much as we'll hear them attack each other.\n\nTrump is trying to paint Harris as \"too liberal\" with further left policies than her boss, President Joe Biden. He's questioning her authenticity and race, trying to highlight that she was tasked with addressing immigration challenges for the Biden administration, and pointing to her record as a prosecutor in California.\n\nMeanwhile, Harris is painting Trump as a criminal who directed his supporters to launch an insurrection after he lost the 2020 election. She said Trump will take freedom away from Americans, and abuse his position of power.\n\nBut, perhaps most importantly, is that we'll see both candidates try to hijack enthusiasm from the other.\n\nAfter all, excitement and enthusiasm are essentially the name of the game this November.\n\nRight now, Harris appears to be winning the enthusiasm competition since Biden dropped out. Most polls since then have shown Harris with a slight lead over Trump nationally, and neck-and-neck in key battleground states.\n\nA CBS-YouGov poll conducted July 30 through Aug. 2 (a week after Biden dropped out and Harris stepped in) found enthusiasm among Democratic voters to \"definitely vote\" this fall increased from 81% earlier in July to 85%. Enthusiasm among Republican voters went down, from 90% saying they will \"definitely vote\" earlier in July to 88%.\n\nThere was also a 16-point increase in enthusiasm among black registered voters.\n\nAmong people who say they sometimes or rarely vote but say they'll definitely vote now, Harris is winning.\n\nHarris waits to see if the ticket will enjoy polling gains after announcing her running mate Tuesday: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, and after the Democratic National Convention later this month.\n\nMuch of Trump's running mate announcement and Republican National Convention enthusiasm was drowned out by the assassination attempt against him earlier in July, though he did see a brief boost in the wake of the shooting.\n\nTrump had lots of excitement about his candidacy in 2016. According to a March 2016 Gallup poll, 65% of Republicans and Republican-leaning voters said they were very or extremely enthusiastic about him, compared to 54% of Democrats who felt that way about Hillary Clinton.\n\nNow, Trump and Harris are in a tight race to win voters' enthusiasm -- and much of what will decide the next president has to do with how voters feel about the candidates.\n\nThe CBS poll finds Harris (59 years old) has an advantage over Trump (78 years old) as having the mental cognitive health to serve. She's also ahead of Trump on being energetic, focused and competent. Trump beats her in the \"tough\" and \"effective\" department.\n\nVoters appear to trust Trump more with the economy, which is often a leading ballot box issue. Just 25% of voters say they'll be financially better off if Harris wins, versus 45% if Trump wins.\n\nSome analysts say Harris is just enjoying the \"honeymoon\" polling right now, and enthusiasm will wane over the coming weeks. Others point to Trump's un-favorability rating (nearly 52% according to FiveThirtyEight polling) and say Harris is a credible threat to Trump getting re-elected.", "source": {"uri": "cbs12.com", {"uri": "2024-08-445846647", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "14:41:22", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T14:41:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T14:37:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/4813418-harris-lead-trump-new-york-poll/", "title": "Harris almost doubles Biden's lead on Trump in New York: Poll", "body": "Vice President Harris has nearly doubled President Biden's lead over former President Trump in New York since launching her campaign last month, according to a new poll.\n\nThe new Siena College poll found Harris has a 14-point lead over the former president with 53 percent of support among New York voters while Trump trails with 39 percent of support from his home state. Harris's lead is up from Biden's 8-point margin over Trump when the poll was taken in late June.\n\nThe poll also showed Harris with a lead over the former president in a six-way race including third-party and independent candidates. Harris received 49 percent of support, Trump received 39 percent and independent candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. received 7 percent.\n\nThe poll additionally found that Harris has support from 86 percent of New York Democrats, which is up from the 75 percent who supported Biden in June. The poll also found that Harris leads among Black voters with 81 percent of support compared to Trump's 11 percent of support.\n\n\"The landscape has changed since the last Siena College poll. The change at the top of the Democratic ticket has had a noticeable, while not dramatic, effect on the horserace,\" Siena College pollster Steven Greenberg said in a statement.\n\nThe poll also found that Harris has expanded the gender gap in support since replacing Biden at the top of the ticket, now leading Trump by 34 percentage points among women in New York. In comparison, Biden had an 18-point lead over Trump among women in June.\n\nGreenberg noted that it was not young voters who helped boost Harris's support.\n\n\"Interestingly, it wasn't young voters that moved the needle. Among voters under 35, Harris leads 49-34%, down a little from the 51-32% lead Biden had in June. Harris' big pickup was among voters 35-54, who favor her 54-40%, after backing Trump 44-41% over Biden in June,\" he said.\n\nThe poll was conducted July 28 to Aug. 1 among 1,199 likely voters in New York. {"uri": "8262293037", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "18:27:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T18:27:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T18:26:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2813382/", "title": "Donald Trump's health increasingly worries voters - ExBulletin", "body": "Fewer voters think Donald Trump is healthy, and more think the 78-year-old Republican is too old to run for office now that President Joe Biden is out of the running for president in 2024, according to a new poll.\n\nA Morning Consult poll of about 2,200 registered voters compared results from when Biden was still in the race to the last poll, when Vice President Kamala Harris was the presumptive Democratic nominee for 2024.\n\nThe results show that now that Trump is facing Harris, 59, fewer voters think Trump is \"healthy,\" falling 6 points from 58% to 52%.\n\nSince Biden dropped out of the race, more than half (51%) of respondents now believe Trump is too old (up from 44%), and the number of people who believe the former president is mentally healthy has dropped 5 points, from 53% to 48%.\n\nThe poll results are the latest sign that Trump will now face the same scrutiny over his age and cognitive abilities that dogged Biden before he dropped out of the race. Trump, 78, is now the oldest presidential candidate in U.S. history and could surpass Biden as the oldest sitting U.S. president in his second term if he wins November's election.\n\nEven before his faltering performance in the June 27 CNN debate, Biden, 81, had already faced concerns about his age, which led him to consider himself too old to run for a second term. Those fears have been reinforced by each gaffe and public speaking error the president has made over the years.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump speaks in Atlanta, Georgia, on August 3. A new poll shows that fewer voters think Trump is healthy compared to when President Joe Biden was running in the 2024 primary. Former President Donald Trump speaks in Atlanta, Georgia, on August 3. A new poll shows that fewer voters think Trump is healthy compared to when President Joe Biden was running in the 2024 primary. Joe Raedle/Getty Images\n\nDespite being only three years younger than Biden and equally prone to gaffes, Trump had never before faced the same level of public concern that he was too old or mentally unfit to run for president again as he ran against him.\n\n\"Unsurprisingly, Biden's replacement with Harris has now erased the Democratic Party's age problem in the eyes of the American electorate. That burden has now been shifted to Trump,\" wrote Eli Yokley, a political analyst at Morning Consult, in his analysis of the results.\n\nNewsweek has reached out to Trump's office via email for comment.\n\nElsewhere, the Morning Consult poll also shows Harris continuing to ride the wave of momentum from her White House battle against Trump.\n\nHarris leads Trump by 4 points (48% to 44) in the latest poll, the largest advantage a Democratic presidential candidate has had over Trump in nearly a year.\n\nHarris also beat Trump among key demographic groups, including independents (42% to 37) and voters ages 18 to 34 (49% to 40).\n\nMorning Consult's latest full poll was conducted Aug. 2-4 among a sample of 11,265 registered voters. {"uri": "8261506823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "09:31:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T09:31:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T09:30:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/08/06/us-news/kamala-harris-fares-better-against-donald-trump-in-ny-than-biden-poll/", "title": "Kamala Harris fares better against Donald Trump in NY than Biden did:...", "body": "Vice President Kamala Harris fares better against former President Donald Trump in the race for the White House among likely New York voters than President Biden did, a new survey released Tuesday reveals.\n\nHarris leads Trump in the Empire State 53% to 39% -- a 14 percentage point lead, the Siena College Poll finds.\n\nIt's the first survey of a head-to-head matchup between Harris and the GOP presidential nominee in New York since the vice president replaced Biden at the top of the Democratic ticket after the unpopular 81-year-old incumbent announced he would not seek re-election.\n\nA Siena poll released in late June found Biden leading Trump by just 8 points, 47% to 39%.\n\nIn a six-way election horse race, Harris leads Trump 49% to 37%, with 7% for Robert Kennedy Jr. and 4% for the other three minor party candidates.\n\n\"The landscape has changed since the last Siena College poll. The change at the top of the Democratic ticket has had a noticeable, while not dramatic, effect on the horse race,\" said Siena College pollster Steven Greenberg.\n\nAccording to the poll, Harris has rallied the base of the Democratic Party.\n\nShe outperforms Biden among women and black voters and was running even with Trump in the battleground suburbs and upstate -- better news for Democrats running in competitive House races.\n\nHarris is backed by 86% of Democrats, up from the 75% support Biden had in June.\n\nHarris captured 81% support from black voters to 11% for Trump, up from 59% for Biden and 29% for Trump in June.\n\nRegistered independent voters support Trump over Harris 47% to 40%. But Trump led Biden among non-party affiliated voters 45% to 28%, so Harris cut into Trump's lead by more than half among indies.\n\nHarris leads with women by a yawning 34 points -- 64% to 30% for Trump, nearly doubling the gender gap.\n\nBiden led Trump among women 51% to 33%.\n\n\"The gender gap has widened with Harris replacing Biden,\" Greenberg said.\n\nTrump led among men -- 49% to 43% for Harris, nearly the same as the 46% to 42% advantage the former GOP president had over Biden.\n\nThe former president also showed strength with two traditionally Democratic leaning voters -- Jews and Hispanics. He split the Jewish vote with Harris (50% to 49%) and Latinos (47% to 48%).\n\n\"Interestingly, it wasn't young voters that moved the needle [for Harris]. Among voters under 35, Harris leads 49-34%, down a little from the 51-32% lead Biden had in June. Harris' big pickup was among voters 35-54, who favor her 54-40%, after backing Trump 44-41% over Biden in June,\" Siena's Greenberg said.\n\nHarris romps in heavily Democratic New York City, 67% to 25% for Trump.\n\nMore important, Harris also is running even with Trump in the suburbs 47% to 47%\n\nThat's a plus for Democrats, when considering Trump trounced Biden by 13 percentage points in the suburbs in Siena College's June survey.\n\nMany of the key battleground congressional races are in the suburbs -- Long Island and Westchester, Rockland, Putnam and Orange counties.\n\nThe match-up was also nearly even upstate, with 47% of voters backing Harris and 45% for Trump.\n\n\"It's better news for Democrats running in a marginal district,\" Greenberg said.\n\nFor House races, 47% of suburban voters support a Democratic candidate, while 44% a Republican -- too close to call.\n\nSimilarly, 44% of upstaters back a Democrat for Congress and 42% a Republican, a dead heat.\n\nFifty three percent of voters in blue-leaning New York had a favorable view of Harris, compared to 43% who didn't.\n\nIn contrast, 59% of respondents had an unfavorable view of native New Yorker Trump, while 39% had a favorable opinion.\n\nMost voters said this presidential race is the most important of their lifetime -- 79% of Democrats, 77% of Republicans and 65% of independents.\n\nIn another important race, incumbent Democratic Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, who is running for a third full, six-year term, leads Republican challenger Mike Sapraicone, a retired NYPD detective by 23 points -- 56% to 33%.\n\n\"With only 13 weeks until election day, Gillibrand is in a strong position to win her fourth election to the United States Senate,\" Greenberg said.\n\nShe won reelection in 2018 with a 34-point victory over her then little known Republican opponent.\n\nThe survey found that 85% of voters did not know enough about Sapraicone to have an opinion, while 27% had no opinion of Gillibrand, who's been in office for 15 years.\n\nThis Siena College Poll was conducted from July 28 through August 1 among 1,199 likely voters, via smart phones and landlines. It has an overall margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.", "source": {"uri": "nypost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "New York Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siena_College", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Siena College"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamala_Harris", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kamala Harris"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Joe Biden"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Democratic Party (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "New York City"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "New York City"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horse_racing", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Horse racing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suburb", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Suburb"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siena", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Siena"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Siena"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Italy"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Jr.", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Robert F. {"uri": "8261979313", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "14:29:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T14:29:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T14:29:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/international/kamala-harris-picks-minnesota-governor-tim-walz-running-mate", "title": "Kamala Harris picks Minnesota governor Tim Walz as running mate", "body": "Kamala Harris picked Tim Walz as her running mate on Tuesday (Aug 6), opting for the Minnesota governor as the partner most likely to complement her in a historic - and bruising - bid for the White House.\n\nWalz had been on a shortlist with a string of other Democratic figures seen as broadening Harris' appeal as she sprints into the contest against Donald Trump.\n\nAiming to make history as the first woman president, Harris - already a trailblazer as the first female and first Black and South Asian vice-president - has little time before Election Day on Nov 5.\n\nThe choice was first reported by CNN early Tuesday morning.\n\nExpectations had always been that Harris would pick a white man to balance the ticket - and the kind of Democrat who can help counter attacks from Republicans that she is too far to the left.\n\nWalz fits that description as a 60-year-old Midwesterner with a folksy manner from a state that could be light years from the coastal elites of California, where Harris comes from, or the East Coast.\n\nHe will also appeal to progressives after having championed popular Democratic policies including cannabis legalisation and increasing worker protections.\n\nThe duo will hit the campaign trail immediately, launching an intense, five-day swing through battleground states starting Tuesday in the biggest prize, Pennsylvania.\n\nFresh from securing the official Democratic nomination overnight, Harris can now head to the national convention in Chicago in two weeks in total control of her party.\n\nIt has been a remarkable journey for Harris, who entered the race only last month when President Joe Biden withdrew, bowing to mounting concerns over his mental acuity and ability at 81 to serve a second term.\n\nIn a campaign that is barely two weeks old, the 59-year-old former prosecutor has obliterated fundraising records, attracted huge crowds and dominated social media on her way to erasing what had been Trump's growing lead in polls over Biden.\n\nThe latest presidential poll by the University of Massachusetts Amherst released Monday has Harris leading Trump nationally by three points - 46 per cent to 43 per cent - compared to a four-point lead for Trump over Biden in January.\n\nIn the swing states that decide the Electoral College contest in US elections, Harris is neck and neck with Trump, who shocked the world with his 2016 presidential victory but was beaten by Biden in 2020.\n\nPicking a vice-presidential running mate was seen as the first big test for Harris in her bid to become the country's chief executive.\n\n\"It tells you about her thought process,\" Amy Walter, a polling expert from Cook Political Report newsletter, told CBS News.\n\nNow, Harris and Walz will face the first test of their ground game as they make the nationwide swing this week from Philadelphia to Wisconsin, Michigan, Arizona and Nevada. Tropical Storm Debby has forced the postponement of a stop in another swing state, Georgia, and according to media reports also North Carolina.\n\nPennsylvania is part of the \"blue wall\" that carried Biden to the White House in 2020, alongside Michigan and Wisconsin. That was one of the main reasons many expected Harris to instead pick that state's governor, Josh Shapiro.\n\nAlso on the vice-presidential shortlist had been former astronaut and current senator Mark Kelly, of Arizona, and Kentucky governor Andy Beshear.\n\nTrump was riding high politically last month after surviving an assassination attempt at a rally, and then using the Republican convention to highlight his image of strength against the physically frail Biden.\n\nBut with Biden's dramatic exit and Harris' fast start, he is scrambling to recalibrate.\n\nAt a rally last Saturday in Georgia, Trump called Harris a \"Marxist\" and a \"radical left freak\", claiming she would cause an \"economic crash\".\n\nThree days earlier, he shocked many when he told an audience of Black journalists that Harris had \"turned Black\" out of political expediency.\n\nWhere Biden often attacked Trump as a threat to democracy, given his unprecedented refusal to accept his loss in 2020, Harris' team has honed a sharper - more meme-friendly - line built around branding Trump and his vice-presidential pick J.D. Vance \"weird\".\n\nOn Saturday, the Harris campaign said Trump was \"scared\" to debate her after he turned down a previously scheduled televised debate on ABC, while saying he'd be ready to debate her on Fox News - a network that has for years given him support. With the November 5 election approaching, Harris has erased Trump's earlier lead, gaining a slight one-point advantage over him nationwide, compared to Trump's previous five-point edge over Biden.\n\nIn key swing states, where the Electoral College contest is decided, Harris and Trump are now evenly matched. This is notable for Harris, who entered the race just last month after President Joe Biden withdrew his reelection bid due to concerns over his age and fitness for a second term.\n\nHarris, Biden's vice president and the first Black and South Asian woman in that role, is in a crucial phase to define her candidacy before Trump does. Her upcoming choice for a running mate is expected to be a significant decision that will shape her campaign's direction.\n\nThe CBS News/YouGov poll also highlights that Trump still leads on economic issues, with 45% of voters expecting to be better off financially if he wins, compared to 25% for Harris. However, Harris is preferred over Trump in terms of temperament, with Trump facing scrutiny over his cognitive health, an issue that now concerns voters more about him than about Harris.\n\nDespite Trump's political high last month, following an assassination attempt and a Republican convention that showcased his vigour, he now faces challenges with Biden's exit and Harris's rapid rise.\n\nTrump has been attacking Harris, calling her names and making controversial remarks, while Harris's campaign has been focusing on portraying Trump and his vice presidential pick, J.D. Vance, as out of touch. {"uri": "2024-08-445939037", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "16:12:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T16:12:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T15:56:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/newsfront/poll-democrat-stranglehold/2024/08/06/id/1175439/", "title": "Siena Poll: Harris Leads Trump by 14 Points in N.Y.", "body": "Former President Donald Trump's goal of winning blue New York has become more difficult since Vice President Kamala Harris replaced President Joe Biden atop the Democratic Party's national ticket, according to Siena College poll results released Tuesday.\n\nHarris leads Trump 53%-39% among likely New York state voters, the first time the Siena College poll has included the vice president against the former president in an election survey.\n\nIn late June, then-presumptive Democrat nominee Biden lead Trump by just 8 points (47%-39%).\n\nThe 81-year-old Biden announced July 21 he was ending his reelection bid.\n\nWith third-party candidates included in the newest poll, Harris leads Trump 49-37%. Independent candidate Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. gets 7%, and three minor party candidates earn a total of 4%.\n\n\"The landscape has changed since the last Siena College poll,\" Siena College pollster Steven Greenberg said. \"The change at the top of the Democratic ticket has had a noticeable, while not dramatic, effect on the horse race\"\n\nTrump still leads (47%-40%) among registered independent voters, but Harris has cut into the former president's advantage. Against Biden, the former president led 45%-28% among unaffiliated voters.\n\nThe former president also fares well among two traditionally Democrat-leaning groups -- Jews and Hispanics. He virtually split the Jewish vote with Harris (50%-49%) and Latinos (47%-48%).\n\nHarris outperforms Biden among women and Black voters and runs even with Trump in battleground New York City suburbs and upstate.\n\nTrump had earned 29% of Black voters against Biden (59%) and only 11% against Harris (81%).\n\nAmong women, Harris leads Trump 64%-30%. Biden led Trump 51%-33% in June.\n\n\"Interestingly, it wasn't young voters that moved the needle [for Harris],\" Greenberg said. \"Among voters under 35, Harris leads 49-34%, down a little from the 51-32% lead Biden had in June. Harris' big pickup was among voters 35-54, who favor her 54-40%, after backing Trump 44-41% over Biden in June.\"\n\nThe vice president is backed by 86% of New York's Democrats, up from the 75% support Biden had in June.\n\nHarris also is running even (47%-47%) with Trump in the city's suburbs, where many key battleground congressional races are located.\n\nTrump trounced Biden by 13 percentage points in the suburbs in June.\n\nThis Siena College Poll was conducted July 28-Aug. 1 among 1,199 likely voters in New York. the results have a margin of error of plus or minus 4.0 percentage points.\n\nCharlie McCarthy \u2709 Charlie McCarthy, a writer/editor at Newsmax, has nearly 40 years of experience covering news, sports, and politics.", "source": {"uri": "newsmax.com", {"uri": "8262398224", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "20:05:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T20:05:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T20:05:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/08/06/g-s1-15701/election-poll-harris-trump", "title": "Poll: Harris jumps to a small national lead over Trump", "body": "Vice President Harris has upended the presidential race and has now built a 51%-48% lead over former President Trump, according to the latest NPR/PBS News/Marist poll.\n\nThat result is 4 points better than just after Harris got into the race two weeks ago when President Biden bowed out. Harris maintains a 3-point lead (48%-45%) when third-party choices are offered, too.\n\nFueling her rise are Black voters, white women with college degrees and women who identify as political independents. She is doing 20 to 30 points better with them than when she first got in, leading to improvement in the suburbs and with white voters overall.\n\nOn the issues, the negative views of the economy are not sticking to Harris the way they did Biden. Trump is still more trusted on the economy, but only by 3 points over Harris (51%-48%), compared to 9 points over Biden (54%-45%) in June.\n\nHarris is also seeing improvement on how she would handle immigration, though Trump is still more trusted on that topic by 6 points (52%-46%). Harris' best issue is handling abortion rights. She has a 15-point advantage on that.\n\nThe survey was conducted from Thursday through Sunday, before Harris picked Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as her vice-presidential running mate. Marist interviewed 1,613 adults via cellphone, landline and online research panels in English and in Spanish. The survey has a margin of error of +/- 3.3 percentage points, meaning results could be roughly 3 points higher or lower.\n\nWomen, Black voters and independents have all moved toward Harris Because of Harris' gains with certain groups, she's also improved her standing in the suburbs and with white voters overall.\n\nBut there's now a 22-point gender gap, which is wider than the margin between Trump and Biden in July. Harris now leads by 13 points with women (55%-42%), but is losing men by 9 points (54%-45%). Considering the margin of error, those are close to the results of the 2020 presidential election, according to exit polls.\n\nHarris' biggest boost is coming with Black voters. She has gone from a 23-point lead with Black voters over Trump a couple of weeks ago, when many voters moved into the undecided camp, to a 54-point lead now. Harris is moving closer to territory where Democrats need to be with Black voters.\n\nSome Black voters, who appeared to be considering Trump, have moved away from him, as he's dropped 10 points with them.\n\nHarris is also now winning independents, something Biden was not doing. Harris is up 9 points with independents (53%-44%). She was down 14 points with them last month. And in early July, Trump was beating Biden by almost 20 points with the group. That's a huge turnaround.\n\nHarris has also improved with white voters overall. Harris has gone from 40% with white voters overall to 46% in this survey, which is closer to where Biden was, and that's very high for a Democrat. In fact, no Democrat has scored that high with white voters in a presidential election since Jimmy Carter in 1976. Biden got 41% in 2020, Barack Obama in 2008 won 43%.\n\nThat improvement is mostly because of college-educated white women. White voters without degrees, a core Trump base group, are heavily in Trump's favor and their margin is unchanged. Two-thirds of college-educated white women, though, are now in Harris' camp, which would be far higher than the percentage that sided with Biden in 2020.\n\nShe's also winning with older voters. Harris is leading Trump by 11 points with Baby Boomers (55%-44%), for example.\n\nLatinos have also moved in Harris' favor. Fifty-eight percent say they would vote for her now, compared to 51% last month. That's still below the 65% Biden won in 2020.\n\nHarris is not where she needs to be with voters under 45 at this point. Biden won them in 2020 by 14 points. Harris and Trump right now are tied with the group. Where Harris does far better than Biden with the group, though, is retaining them when third parties are introduced.\n\nBiden was seeing double-digit drop offs with Gen Z/Millennials, for example. Harris, on the other hand, maintains and slightly expands her margin when respondents have a choice of candidates other than the two major-party picks.\n\nHarris is benefiting from a boost in enthusiasm with core Democratic voter groups\n\nBlack, Latino and younger voters are saying they're more fired up to vote now that Harris is in the race.\n\nBlack voters, Latinos and Gen Z/Millennial voters have all jumped double-digits in saying they're definitely voting.\n\nIn July, just 71% of Black voters, 68% of Latinos and 65% of Gen Z/Millennials said they were definitely voting, among the lowest of any groups.\n\nBut now, that's up to 81% with Black voters, 84% with Latinos and 80% with Gen Z/Millennials, closer to being on par with white voters than in previous surveys.\n\nThird parties seeing their lowest marks of the election\n\nWith Harris in the race, people appear to be moving away from third parties.\n\nAll of the third-party candidates are seeing their worst scores since Marist started asking about them in April. Robert F. Kennedy Jr., running as an independent, is down to just 5%. Professor Cornel West, also running as an independent, Green Party candidate Jill Stein and Libertarian Chase Oliver are all polling at or below 1%.\n\nKennedy still does best with those who have an unfavorable opinion of both Trump and Harris, pulling in about a third of those voters.\n\nPeople are split on who they think will win, but far more say Harris will than they said of Biden\n\nLast month, respondents were 20 points more likely to say Trump would beat Biden (59%-39%). Now, they're split (48%-48%).\n\nNotably, independents have flipped from 58% thinking Trump would win to 52% now saying they think Harris will.\n\nPeople are also more satisfied with their choices, though only 47% say they are compared to 50% who say they are not. In June, there was a 10-point difference between people satisfied (42%) and those who were dissatisfied with their choices (52%).\n\nBeing honest and trustworthy is the most important quality for a president\n\nWhile trustworthiness was the most important quality for Democrats and independent voters, a plurality of Republicans said a \"strong leader\" was most important to them.\n\nAll signs continue to point to a close election - not just in the presidential but also for Congress\n\nForty-seven percent said they want to see Democrats in control of Congress, while 45% said Republicans. That 2-point advantage is unchanged from June.\n\nDemocrats traditionally need a wider advantage in that score to make significant gains - in 2022, when they denied Republicans from winning a wave of House seats, they had a 4-point edge in the Marist poll; in 2020, it was 8, but Democrats lost House seats; they were +6 in 2018 and made significant gains, however; in 2014, when Republicans won seats, Republicans were +5 on the question.\n\nThe congressional ballot and the change in numbers of seats don't always correlate cleanly because of where the most competitive seats are that cycle. In this cycle, for example, many are in suburban areas in New York, California and around Philadelphia, where Democrats have advantages in presidential years because of higher turnout among their core voter groups.\n\nBiden's approval is up\n\nNow that Biden has dropped out of the race, his approval rating is seeing a bounce.\n\nHis approval is now 46%, which is the highest since February of 2023 and up 5 points since last month.", "source": {"uri": "npr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "NPR"}, "authors": [{"uri": "domenico_montanaro@npr.org", "name": "Domenico Montanaro", "type": "author", {"uri": "8261976407", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "14:27:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T14:27:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T14:27:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/harris-picks-minnesota-governor-walz-as-running-mate/article_c7247086-22ff-584c-aa59-a9f08d0c2b20.html", "title": "Harris picks Minnesota governor Walz as running mate", "body": "Kamala Harris picked Tim Walz as her running mate Tuesday, opting for the Minnesota governor as the partner most likely to complement her in a historic -- and bruising -- bid for the White House.\n\nWalz had been on a shortlist with a string of other Democratic figures seen as broadening Harris's appeal as she sprints into the contest against Donald Trump.\n\nAiming to make history as the first woman president, Harris -- already a trailblazer as the first female and first Black and South Asian vice president -- has little time before Election Day on November 5.\n\nThe choice was first reported by CNN early Tuesday morning.\n\nExpectations had always been that Harris would pick a white man to balance the ticket -- and the kind of Democrat who can help counter attacks from Republicans that she is too far to the left.\n\nWalz fits that description as a 60-year-old Midwesterner with a folksy manner from a state that could be light years from the coastal elites of California, where Harris comes from, or the East Coast.\n\nHe will also appeal to progressives after having championed popular Democratic policies including cannabis legalization and increasing worker protections.\n\nThe duo will hit the campaign trail immediately, launching an intense, five-day swing through battleground states starting Tuesday in the biggest prize, Pennsylvania.\n\nFresh from securing the official Democratic nomination overnight, Harris can now head to the national convention in Chicago in two weeks in total control of her party.\n\nIt has been a remarkable journey for Harris, who only entered the race last month when President Joe Biden withdrew, bowing to mounting concerns over his mental acuity and ability at 81 to serve a second term.\n\nIn a campaign that is barely two weeks old, the 59-year-old former prosecutor has obliterated fundraising records, attracted huge crowds and dominated social media on her way to erasing what had been Trump's growing lead in polls over Biden.\n\nThe latest presidential poll by the University of Massachusetts Amherst released Monday has Harris leading Trump nationally by three points -- 46 percent to 43 percent -- compared to a four-point lead for Trump over Biden in January.\n\n- First major test - More from this section Surging Harris, Trump spar over debate dates Lyles taking athletics back to 'Bolt territory', says Coe Lyles bids for Olympic 100m glory as Djokovic faces Alcaraz\n\nIn the swing states that decide the Electoral College contest in US elections, Harris is neck and neck with Trump, who shocked the world with his 2016 presidential victory but was beaten by Biden in 2020.\n\nPicking a vice presidential running mate was seen as the first big test for Harris in her bid to become the country's chief executive.\n\n\"It tells you about her thought process,\" Amy Walter, a polling expert from Cook Political Report newsletter, told CBS News.\n\nNow, Harris and Walz will face the first test of their ground game as they make the nationwide swing this week from Philadelphia to Wisconsin, Michigan, Arizona and Nevada. Tropical Storm Debby has forced the postponement of a stop in another swing state, Georgia, and according to media reports also North Carolina.\n\nPennsylvania is part of the \"blue wall\" that carried Biden to the White House in 2020, alongside Michigan and Wisconsin. That was one of the main reasons many expected Harris to instead pick that state's governor, Josh Shapiro.\n\nAlso on the vice presidential shortlist had been former astronaut and current senator Mark Kelly, of Arizona, and Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear.\n\nTrump was riding high politically last month after surviving an assassination attempt at a rally, and then using the Republican convention to highlight his image of vigor against the physically frail Biden.\n\nBut with Biden's dramatic exit and Harris's fast start, he is scrambling to recalibrate.\n\nAt a rally last Saturday in Georgia, Trump called Harris a \"Marxist\" and a \"radical left freak,\" claiming she would cause an \"economic crash.\"\n\nThree days earlier, he shocked many when he told an audience of Black journalists that Harris had \"turned Black\" out of political expediency.\n\nWhere Biden often attacked Trump as a threat to democracy, given his unprecedented refusal to accept his loss in 2020, Harris's team has honed a sharper -- more meme-friendly -- line built around branding Trump and his vice presidential pick J.D. Vance \"weird.\"\n\nOn Saturday, the Harris campaign said Trump was \"scared\" to debate her after he turned down a previously scheduled televised debate on ABC, while saying he'd be ready to debate her on Fox News -- a network that has for years given him support.\n\nsms-ft/nro", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8262405511", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "20:12:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T20:12:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T20:11:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.bpr.org/npr-news/2024-08-06/poll-harris-jumps-to-a-small-national-lead-over-trump", "title": "Poll: Harris jumps to a small national lead over Trump", "body": "Vice President Harris has upended the presidential race and has now built a 51%-48% lead over former President Trump, according to the latest NPR/PBS News/Marist poll.\n\nThat result is 4 points better than just after Harris got into the race two weeks ago when President Biden bowed out. Harris maintains a 3-point lead (48%-45%) when third-party choices are offered, too.\n\nLoading...\n\nFueling her rise are Black voters, white women with college degrees and women who identify as political independents. She is doing 20 to 30 points better with them than when she first got in, leading to improvement in the suburbs and with white voters overall.\n\nOn the issues, the negative views of the economy are not sticking to Harris the way they did Biden. Trump is still more trusted on the economy, but only by 3 points over Harris (51%-48%), compared to 9 points over Biden (54%-45%) in June.\n\nHarris is also seeing improvement on how she would handle immigration, though Trump is still more trusted on that topic by 6 points (52%-46%). Harris' best issue is handling abortion rights. She has a 15-point advantage on that.\n\nLoading...\n\nThe survey was conducted from Thursday through Sunday, before Harris picked Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as her vice-presidential running mate. Marist interviewed 1,613 adults via cellphone, landline and online research panels in English and in Spanish. The survey has a margin of error of +/- 3.3 percentage points, meaning results could be roughly 3 points higher or lower.\n\nBecause of Harris' gains with certain groups, she's also improved her standing in the suburbs and with white voters overall.\n\nBut there's now a 22-point gender gap, which is wider than the margin between Trump and Biden in July. Harris now leads by 13 points with women (55%-42%), but is losing men by 9 points (54%-45%). Considering the margin of error, those are close to the results of the 2020 presidential election, according to exit polls.\n\nHarris' biggest boost is coming with Black voters. She has gone from a 23-point lead with Black voters over Trump a couple of weeks ago, when many voters moved into the undecided camp, to a 54-point lead now. Harris is moving closer to territory where Democrats need to be with Black voters.\n\nSome Black voters, who appeared to be considering Trump, have moved away from him, as he's dropped 10 points with them.\n\nHarris is also now winning independents, something Biden was not doing. Harris is up 9 points with independents (53%-44%). She was down 14 points with them last month. And in early July, Trump was beating Biden by almost 20 points with the group. That's a huge turnaround.\n\nHarris has also improved with white voters overall. Harris has gone from 40% with white voters overall to 46% in this survey, which is closer to where Biden was, and that's very high for a Democrat. In fact, no Democrat has scored that high with white voters in a presidential election since Jimmy Carter in 1976. Biden got 41% in 2020, Barack Obama in 2008 won 43%.\n\nThat improvement is mostly because of college-educated white women. White voters without degrees, a core Trump base group, are heavily in Trump's favor and their margin is unchanged. Two-thirds of college-educated white women, though, are now in Harris' camp, which would be far higher than the percentage that sided with Biden in 2020.\n\nShe's also winning with older voters. Harris is leading Trump by 11 points with Baby Boomers (55%-44%), for example.\n\nLatinos have also moved in Harris' favor. Fifty-eight percent say they would vote for her now, compared to 51% last month. That's still below the 65% Biden won in 2020.\n\nHarris is not where she needs to be with voters under 45 at this point. Biden won them in 2020 by 14 points. Harris and Trump right now are tied with the group. Where Harris does far better than Biden with the group, though, is retaining them when third parties are introduced.\n\nBiden was seeing double-digit drop offs with Gen Z/Millennials, for example. Harris, on the other hand, maintains and slightly expands her margin when respondents have a choice of candidates other than the two major-party picks.\n\nBlack, Latino and younger voters are saying they're more fired up to vote now that Harris is in the race.\n\nBlack voters, Latinos and Gen Z/Millennial voters have all jumped double-digits in saying they're definitely voting.\n\nIn July, just 71% of Black voters, 68% of Latinos and 65% of Gen Z/Millennials said they were definitely voting, among the lowest of any groups.\n\nBut now, that's up to 81% with Black voters, 84% with Latinos and 80% with Gen Z/Millennials, closer to being on par with white voters than in previous surveys.\n\nWith Harris in the race, people appear to be moving away from third parties.\n\nAll of the third-party candidates are seeing their worst scores since Marist started asking about them in April. Robert F. Kennedy Jr., running as an independent, is down to just 5%. Professor Cornel West, also running as an independent, Green Party candidate Jill Stein and Libertarian Chase Oliver are all polling at or below 1%.\n\nKennedy still does best with those who have an unfavorable opinion of both Trump and Harris, pulling in about a third of those voters.\n\nLast month, respondents were 20 points more likely to say Trump would beat Biden (59%-39%). Now, they're split (48%-48%).\n\nNotably, independents have flipped from 58% thinking Trump would win to 52% now saying they think Harris will.\n\nPeople are also more satisfied with their choices, though only 47% say they are compared to 50% who say they are not. In June, there was a 10-point difference between people satisfied (42%) and those who were dissatisfied with their choices (52%).\n\nWhile trustworthiness was the most important quality for Democrats and independent voters, a plurality of Republicans said a \"strong leader\" was most important to them.\n\nForty-seven percent said they want to see Democrats in control of Congress, while 45% said Republicans. That 2-point advantage is unchanged from June.\n\nDemocrats traditionally need a wider advantage in that score to make significant gains - in 2022, when they denied Republicans from winning a wave of House seats, they had a 4-point edge in the Marist poll; in 2020, it was 8, but Democrats lost House seats; they were +6 in 2018 and made significant gains, however; in 2014, when Republicans won seats, Republicans were +5 on the question.\n\nThe congressional ballot and the change in numbers of seats don't always correlate cleanly because of where the most competitive seats are that cycle. In this cycle, for example, many are in suburban areas in New York, California and around Philadelphia, where Democrats have advantages in presidential years because of higher turnout among their core voter groups.\n\nNow that Biden has dropped out of the race, his approval rating is seeing a bounce.\n\nHis approval is now 46%, which is the highest since February of 2023 and up 5 points since last month.", "source": {"uri": "bpr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "bpr.org"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_politician", "type": "org", "score": 5,
